ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / After waiting for the spirit bear to appear all day, as the day passed and we were ready to leave the river, we were rewarded.

This big male was probably sleeping under the tree all day without us knowing he was just a few metres away. With his little, still sleepy eyes, he acknowledged our presence and continued to patrol the river edge, stopping from time to time to fish.

The Kermode or spirit bear is one of the rarest bears in the world. This subspecies of the American black bear has white or cream-coloured fur, due to a unique recessive gene. Their home is the well-named Great Bear Rainforest in B.C. on Canada‚Äôs West Coast.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#spiritbear #kermodebear #cangeo #explorecanada #canada #britishcolumbia #greatbearrainforest #wildlifephotography #naturephotography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bear fur comes in a range of colours, from light brown to dark brown and black to blonde. Their fur often changes from one season to the next.

From a young age, cubs often have a light-coloured collar, which usually disappears when they become adults.

I love this gorgeous blond cub I photograph in the Chilko region in British Columbia, Canada.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #Britishcolumbia #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / When photographing wildlife, I try to ‚Äúwork my subject‚Äù whenever possible. Basically, this means shooting with different lenses while trying every possible angle.

When the opportunity presents itself, I prefer to lie on the ground and be at eye level with my subject.

Depending on the animal I‚Äôm photographing, whether it‚Äôs a docile or dangerous animal, shy or fearless, I choose one lens over the other.
I love wide-angle portraits as they give me the chance to get close and personal while including the background habitat. Sometimes, though, I find it too intrusive and I opt for a telephoto lens instead.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#climatechange #seal #harpseal #wildlifephotography #canada #explorecanada #quebec #magdalenIsland

Photo by @daisygilardini / The snow petrel is one of my favorites of the Antarctic birds, along with the terns. They are a small but super strong bird and are one of only three birds that breed exclusively in Antarctica.
Snow petrels produce a stomach oil that can be used to feed the chicks. The stomach oil is a source of food for themselves as well, during long flights. It can even be used to spray out of their mouths as a defense against predators.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#petrel #snowpetrel #birdphotography #Antarctica #climatechange #climatechangeisreal

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Emperor penguins are unique among penguins. Their breeding season begins in the Southern autumn (April), when the sea ice is strong enough for the colony to assemble. When the female lays her egg, she passes it to her mate and leaves to feed on her own. She will remain at sea, foraging for food, until spring. The female will return in July, often to find a newly hatched chick. The male then hands over the chick and leaves, to feed at sea. The male will periodically return with food during this time, to help raise the chick. Males and females alternate between spending time with their chick and foraging at sea.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

#penguin #emperorpenguin #Antarctica #snowhillisland #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #wildlifephotography #birdphotography

Photo by @daisygilardini / Arctic hares live in the tundra biome, above the tree line, and are mainly herbivorous. As with many other cold-climate animals, their body is well adapted to cope with extreme temperatures.
They have a relatively low surface-area-to-volume ratio. Compared to other hares, they have shorter legs and ears and stockier bodies. Even though 20% of their body mass is fat for insulation, what really keeps them warm is their thick fur.
More southerly populations change color to a blue-gray in the summer, in order to camouflage themselves with their surroundings, while northern populations stay white year-round.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#hare #arctichare #churchill #manitoba #canada

Photo @jasonedwardsng // The striated caracara is listed as near threatened due to its highly restricted global population range and relatively small population size.

They are intelligent and acrobatic predators. Aboard the HMS Beagle, Charles Darwin penned: ‚ÄúThey were constantly flying on board the vessel when in the harbor, and it was necessary to keep a good lookout to prevent the leather being torn from the rigging. These birds are very mischievous and inquisitive; they will pick up almost anything from the ground; a large black glazed hat was carried nearly a mile‚Ä¶‚Äù

Please find my latest book ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô in my bio @jasonedwardsng

#birdofprey #caracara #falklands #charlesdarwin #threatenedspecies #wildlifeconservation

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Where‚Äôs the camera?! That's most likely what this tiger is thinking in this series of images which ran as the opener for my Nat Geo photo story on Kaziranga National Park in India. He‚Äôs looking around because he can hear the sound of a camera trap trigger that has been activated by an infrared beam. I love using camera traps because I can get closer and lower to the animals than any other technique in my photo toolbox. Kaziranga has the highest density of tigers in the world with roughly 1 individual per 5 km. I highly recommend this place for rhinos, elephants, and the tigers themselves! Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more tiger images
.

ph_descripcion:
Photo @jasonedwardsng // Endangered Sri Lankan Elephant beginning, middle, and end.

Elephants change the structure and biodiversity of landscapes and ecosystems. Through their immense size, they remove trees allowing other plant species to colonise, and they even alter the course of waterways. They plough and fertilise the soil, and they are ecosystems for many other species that live on them.

See more on my story about these incredible pachyderms in ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô in my store in the link in my bio @jasonedwardsng.

#srilanka #natgeowild #endangeredspecies #elephant #conservation

Did you know that if mountain lions recolonised the eastern United States 708,600 deer-related vehicle collisions, 155 human deaths, and 21,400 human injuries could be prevented over the next 30 years? That‚Äôs over 2 billion dollars in insurance savings. Yep, by hunting deer, big cats save lives! Who would have thought that?

Photo by @daisygilardini / Male and female reindeer both grow antlers. Males shed their antlers at the end of the mating season, usually in early December. Females keep their antlers throughout the winter months, when they may be pregnant and at their most vulnerable.
I shot this image in early April, during my recent assignment in Svalbard. These two females started to spar whenever they got close to each other, competing for food in small patches of ground with no snow. The dominant females are often those with the largest antlers.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#Svalbard #reindeer #svalbardreindeer #wildlifephotography #iceberg #arctic

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Here is a tiger from the Sundarbans of Bengal, India. We had just left a fenced-off walkway and gotten back in the boat when I saw 4-5 boats close together in the distance. I asked what was going on and the reply was "Tiger!!" As the tiger was crossing this mangrove forest he stopped and looked at me. The Sundarbans of India and Bangladesh have always been the largest wetlands in the world. Today they are disappearing as waters rise and the land is covered with water. Climate Change is here, so where will these tigers go?

Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cats.

Photo by @daisygilardini / Pure power and focus! I love being among bears during the salmon run. It always impresses how much power and focus they show while fishing, and yet they can be so goofy at the same time.
Their techniques vary depending on their mother's teaching, and their confidence grows with age. The youngest tend to splash around, running like crazy, and seldom catch a fish. The older ones just walk up quietly and observe the salmon for a while without moving a single muscle. Then, with a precise jump and powerful paws, they firmly catch the fish, one after another.
Just before hibernation, bears enter a phase called hyperphagia, in which their appetite is dramatically increased. They can eat several dozen fish in one session, for a total of more than 50 kg (110 pounds).
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #Alaska #katmainationalpark #conservation #power

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / The ivory gull is a small, beautiful, all-white gull, and is one of the most sought-after Arctic species by birders around the world.
Ivory gulls spend most of their lives along the edges of constantly shifting pack ice, and in winter near large areas of open water surrounded by sea ice, or polynyas. They are opportunistic scavengers, and for this reason, they often follow polar bears and groups of seals.
It is rare to see an ivory gull, let alone a big flock of them, so I was in disbelief when this past September while cruising along a large glacier on the eastern coast of Spitsbergen, we came across a flock of hundreds of them.
There were so many that it took me a while to figure out how to photograph them. We spent a good three hours cruising among the icebergs in front of the glacier, watching their behaviour and taking advantage of some great photographic opportunities. I look forward to sharing more of these images in the coming weeks and months.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#ivorygull #arctic #svalbard #birdphotography #wildlifephotography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / I‚Äôm not a big fan of flash as a rule but occasionally, when really necessary, I‚Äôll use flash for a bit of fill. I always pay attention to the animal‚Äôs reaction though, and if I see any negative impact I‚Äôll immediately stop and look for an alternative solution.
One stormy morning at Volunteer Point in the Falkland Islands (Malvinas), the light suddenly dropped dramatically when the sky turned black with menacing clouds.
I love dramatic skies, so instead of giving up due to the lack of light, I decided to try a bit of fill flash with these penguins.
It‚Äôs extremely challenging to get it right because penguins‚Äô shiny belly feathers are extremely reflective, and it‚Äôs all too easy to ‚Äúburn out‚Äù the whites and lose all the detail as a result.
I usually underexpose the flash by 1 stop, to avoid too much contrast.
Follow me @DaisyGilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#pegnuing #kingpenguin #falklandIslands #malvinas #conservation

Photo @jasonedwardsng - Male lions face a fraught time when females in the pride are in oestrus. They have to chaperone the lioness and keep rival and potentially more powerful males at bay, risking injury and death. If more than one female is receptive, then there is an even greater risk of conflict with other males.

Check out my new book ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô featuring my National Geographic assignments in my bio link.

#lions #natgeowild #bigcat #serengeti #lionking #lioness

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @DaisyGilardini / A close encounter with a young Galapagos sea lion.
Sea lions have thick, long whiskers, but their looks can be deceiving. Their whiskers are some of the most sensitive in the animal kingdom. They use their whiskers to guide movement, look for food and explore the world around them. Basically, they use their whiskers the way we humans use our fingertips.
In this instance, the young sea lion was trying to figure out my camera dome by extending his whiskers.
#galapagos #galapagosislands #sealion #underwaterphotography #curiosity

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @DaisyGilardini / Polar bears evolved to live in the cold. Two layers of fur ‚Äî one of which has hollow hair ‚Äî black skin, and a thick layer of fat protect them from frigid temperatures.
Polar bears‚Äô ears and tails are small, to avoid unnecessary heat dispersal. Their paws are huge, allowing them to walk on thin ice.
Their black footpads are covered by papillae which, coupled with their long claws, act as a crampon effect, gripping the ice while walking.
Polar bears have long necks for swimming and for catching seals through breathing holes in the ice.
Follow me @DaisyGilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#canada #manitoba #polarbear #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / The waved albatross is listed as critically endangered on the IUCN‚Äôs Red List of vulnerable and threatened species. The main threats to its survival are the climate crisis and fishing bycatch.
The waved albatross is the only albatross species found in the tropics. Espa√±ola Island in the Galapagos Islands is one of the few places, where they reproduce. They are the largest bird species in the entire archipelago, with a wingspan of up to 2.5 meters (8 feet).
They are monogamous, meaning they mate with a single partner for life. They perform fascinating courtship dances that include bowing heads, stretching legs, spreading wings, waddling walks, and circling and clacking bills.
After courtship, females lay a single egg on bare ground. The chick hatches two months later and is ready to leave the nest in another five and half months‚Äô time.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#galapagos #wavedalbatross #albatross #birdphotography #couple #tenderness #courtship #conservation

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Female leopard sleeping in a tree protecting her impala under a full moon.
There are nine sub-species of leopards on Earth, occurring from the southern tip of South Africa's Cape mountains to the island of Java in southeast Asia. The leopard can live in true deserts, tropical forests, and even in the Russian tundra where it drops to below 10 degrees celsius! The biggest threats facing leopards in Africa include the illegal skin trade, wire snare poaching, and human-leopard conflict.
.

Photo by @daisygilardini / The Atlantic puffin population in Svalbard is estimated to be around roughly 10,000 pairs, making it one of the last surviving population strongholds of this fascinating seabird.

That population has been under stress in the last few years, though. Scientists suspect the decline is due to a combination of factors, including predation from invasive species, pollution, and a shortage of food due to overfishing.

I photographed this puffin on a beautiful summer‚Äôs day at the peak of the breeding season. In the winter, puffins lose the bright coloration of their bills and feet, but in summer, they‚Äôre full of life and on full display.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#svalbard #norway #puffin #atlanticpuffin #birdphotography #conservation
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo WILD on January 20, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

The Kamchatka brown bear is the largest bear in the whole of Eurasia. A type of brown bear, they grow up to 3 meters tall and can weigh 650 kg. They eat everything from seven different types of salmon to pine nuts and berries.
In a few remote protected areas in Russia's Kamchatka peninsula, these brown bears reach their highest densities on Earth. However, increased road construction and mineral exploration are fragmenting populations across the peninsula. There may be only 10-14,000 of these incredible bears left in Kamchatka (an area the size of California).
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo WILD on January 19, 2023.

Photo by @stevewinterphoto // Did you know that there are about 26 individual leopards/100 square kilometers that live in the Sanjay Gandhi National Park in India? If there was ever a case study of big cats coexisting with people, this is definitely it. This is the highest density of leopards recorded anywhere across their range, largely owed to the large stray dog population living around the park!
.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / A young brown bear mother plays with her only cub.
Bears usually give birth to three cubs. The mortality rate of cubs during their first year of life is around 30-40%, which means that in some cases only one in three cubs will survive to see their second year.
When a mother is left with only one cub, field biologists have found that the mother is much more inclined to interact and play with the sole surviving cub. Play is an extremely important part of the process of growing up for any cub. It helps the cub to grow stronger, build self-confidence, and learn to socialize.
#brownbear #grizzlybear #Alaska #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Justin Grubb @journeying_justin / A green lynx spider waits in ambush for insects lured in by the rotting smell of this pitcher plant in Central Florida. This spider has developed a cunning way of hunting by making the plant do all the work while it sits and waits to grab unsuspecting prey. The spider avoids falling into the plant by carefully fastening a silk anchor on the top leaf of the pitcher plant. These spiders are not found exclusively on pitcher plants and will also hunt other areas of high insect activity, such as flowers and fruiting plants.

Found in bogs, wetlands, and areas with low-nutrient soil, pitcher plants produce a juice that attracts insects and traps them inside the plant to be digested. This unique adaptation has evolved so the plant has access to additional nutrient sources not naturally found in the soils where it grows.

Follow me @journeying_justin for more images and wildlife stories.

#natgeowild #natgeo #spiders
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo WILD on January 11, 2023.

Photo by @daisygilardini / I simply love to be in the forest early in the morning and hear it waking up . . . the ravens announcing the arrival of the bears, the mist rising from the river as the sun's first rays appear. It's a mystical experience that takes you back to the origin of creation.

The Great Bear Rainforest is the largest coastal temperate rainforest in the world, and one of the most pristine places I have ever visited. Its territory extends from the central coast of British Columbia to BC's north coast, covering an area roughly 64,000 km¬≤ in size.

The forest is home to grizzly bears, black bears, and Kermode/spirit bears, among other animals.
#greatbearrainforest #britishcolumbia #bear #blackbear #conservation
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo WILD on January 10, 2023.

Photo by @carltonward / Limpkins live all over the American tropics. In the United States, limpkins can only be found in Florida and southern Georgia. In Florida, these wading birds were almost hunted to extinction at the beginning of the 20th century, but legal protections have allowed the population to recover and thrive, relying on lakes and wetlands throughout the Florida Wildlife Corridor.

Follow @carltonward for more wild moments from Florida.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Roughly 15,000 grizzly bears live in the Canadian province of British Columbia. This represents a quarter of the entire North American population and half the Canadian population.
Habitat loss and fragmented territories remain a threat to their survival, along with human-caused mortality as a result of trophy hunting and the eradication of problem bears.
A recent study by a BC-based research team, published in the summer of 2020, of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), found that Canadian bears are changing their behaviour to survive in more populated areas.
Clayton T. Lamb, the co-author of the study, said bears living in 'coexistence landscapes,' in proximity to people, are increasing their nocturnal activity by two to three percent every year.
This behaviour decreases the chances of human disturbance, interaction, and conflict.
#humanconflict #conservation #grizzlybear #britishcolumbia #canada

Photo by Justin Grubb @journeying_justin / When wolves are on the hunt, ravens are right behind them, looking for the opportunity to be the first scavenger on the kill. These intelligent birds follow hunting parties to beat out their fellow scavengers for food.

The raven has a haunting call that can break the silence of winter in Yellowstone National Park. With a hoarse croaking kraak and kloo-klok, ravens talk over long distances but are also known to use subtle body language to communicate with one another.

Follow me @journeying_justin for more images and wildlife stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini / I am totally in love with the Svalbard reindeer. How could you not be, with such a cute muzzle?
They‚Äôre endemic to Svalbard and are the smallest of the seven subspecies of reindeer found in the Arctic.
They have adapted well to survive the harsh environment. They‚Äôre very sedentary and therefore have low energy demands, especially in winter when food resources are low and they have to rely on their reserves of body fat.

Photo @jasonedwardsng - The Snares penguin inhabits a tiny, remote group of islands of the same name south of New Zealand. Primarily feeding on krill, squid, and small fish, these robust birds are listed as Vulnerable, given their reduced numbers and limited habitat.

Please check out my latest book "Icebergs to Iguanas" in the link in my bio.

Photo by Justin Grubb @journeying_justin / One of the most adaptable animals in North America, the red fox can be observed in neighborhood backyards, urban areas, and even extremely remote mountain ranges.

I encountered this sleepy fox in Yellowstone National Park, where they are the smallest canid species found in the park and primarily feed on small rabbits, mice, voles, and carrion. Because of their thick coats, they are active all winter long and have no problem with taking short naps on top of snow banks.

Follow me @journeying_justin for more images and wildlife stories.

#natgeowild #natgeo #yellowstonenationalpark #fox

Photo by @daisygilardini / As climate change progresses and sea ice is melting, forcing more polar bears ashore in more places, polar bears have been observed to consume more terrestrial food resources.
In Svalbard, some polar bears have been specializing in hunting reindeer and reside year-round in the same fjord systems.
The food they find on land has, however, less energy reach compared to the fatty seals they are used to hunting while on the ice.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#Churchill #Manitoba #polarbear

Photo by @daisygilardini | A night of ice and fire.
You never know what the Antarctic night will hold for you. Sometimes a promising sunset will turn on you quickly when low clouds obstruct the horizon. Sometimes you think nothing is going to happen, and at the last minute, an opening will allow the light to peek through the clouds in an explosion of color. The key is to always be ready, in the right spot at the right moment, and grab the opportunity when it arises.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#Antarctica #penguin #sunset #polar #chinstrappenguin #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #wildlifephotography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Each spring, humpback whales in the Southern Hemisphere migrate south from the tropical waters of the Pacific to the rich Antarctic waters to feed.
Their diet consists mainly of crustaceans ‚Äî krill, plankton, and small fish ‚Äî which they filter through a filter feeder inside their mouths called a baleen.
They are huge animals that range between 12 and 16 meters (39-52 feet). During the feeding season, they can eat up to 2000/2500 kg of krill (plankton or fish) a day.
They have developed an interesting technique called bubble-net feeding to maximize their catch.
When emerging from a deep dive below a dense cluster of food, they swim in a circle and release bubbles that create a spiral wall that helps group their prey together. They then surface right in the middle of the bubble wall with their mouths open.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#conservation #whales #humpbackwhale #bubblenetting #humpback #wildlifephotography #naturephotography

Photo by Justin Grubb @journeying_justin / I took this photo in the spring after male elk began to lose their antlers. This is an automatic biological response to the change in available light during the day and is triggered by hormones in the animal's blood. Their antlers will fall off but will provide valuable resources such as calcium for scavenging animals.

The two little knobs on the elk's head are called pedicles and I think they make the elk look like he is wearing little goggles.

When the daylight hours increase as summer rolls in, male elk will begin growing their next set of antlers in preparation for the breeding season. Every year by September, bull males will grow large antlers, sometimes weighing up to 18 kg or 40 lbs. They will use them to fight other males for the opportunity to mate.

Follow me @journeying_justin for more images and wildlife stories.

#natgeowild #natgeo #yellowstonenationalpark #elk

Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bear fur comes in a range of colours, from light brown to dark brown and black to blonde. Their fur often changes from one season to the next. From a young age, cubs often have a light-coloured collar, which usually disappears when they become adults.
I really hope that this beautiful BC bear, now three-years-old, will keep its wonderful colouring, with its super cute white ear tips and blonde collar!
Bear coats are naturally thicker and more coarse during the winter months. In spring, as the weather warms, bears shed their inner fur and guard hairs. They can look really funny and shabby during this transition period.
Interestingly, the name ‚Äúgrizzly‚Äù derives from its silver-tipped, greyish ‚Äî aka grizzled ‚Äî fur, though it's commonly believed that the name is taken from the word "grisly," meaning horrible. Not true!

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #BritishColumbia #conservation

Photo by @daisygilardini / Anticipation is key in wildlife photography.
Bears simply love salmon. During the fall salmon run, they often dive headfirst into the river to catch salmon. When they re-emerge, they shake off excess water trapped in their fur.
Timing and shutter speed are critical. If you succeed at freezing the action, the results can be really cool.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sandesh_kadur // The fastest non-flying creature in the canopy, gibbons can attain speeds of over 35 miles per hour, swaying from branch to branch in a form of arboreal locomotion called brachiation. The golden-cheeked gibbon, going by the species name of Nomascus gabriellae, probably undergoes more costume changes throughout its life than most other animals. The females are born blonde, turn black as they grow, and then turn back into blonde, retaining just a little black cap on the top of their heads. The males, on the other hand, are born blonde but turn black, sporting the distinctive golden-colored cheeks that give them the name. As with all gibbons, small families vocalize at dawn, with both sexes singing a distinctive song. Found wherever there are old-growth forests left in Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos, this beautiful old-world ape is sadly an endangered species, with a few thousand individuals left in the wild. Vietnam‚Äôs Cat Tien National Park is one of the strongholds for this species.

Follow me @sandesh_kadur as I travel the world's last wildernesses, bringing you stories of fascinating creatures from the remotest corners of our planet.

#mammalwatching #gibbons #endangered #apes #wildvietnam #Felisimages #primates #cattiennationalpark #goldencheekedgibbon

Photo by @daisygilardini / Weddell seals feed mainly on fish, squid, and other invertebrates, such as krill. They are extraordinary divers. They can dive up to depths of 600m and spend more than an hour underwater.
They are the southernmost breeding mammal on Earth and can be found from New Zealand's Sub-Antarctic Islands to the Ross Sea in Antarctica.
I simply love their cat-like faces and the beautiful patterns of their grey coats.
They often come on land or lie on ice to rest and digest their food, so it's not that easy to photograph them and capture their expressions, as they're very passive when out of the water.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#Antarctica #seal #weddellseal #conservation #climatechange

Photo by @daisygilardini / Porpoising gentoo penguin. While swimming, penguins often leap in and out of the water in rapid series of short bursts. This allows them to breathe regularly and also confuses and disorients potential predators.
It‚Äôs a challenge to freeze a frame of them in the air during this behavior because they‚Äôre unpredictable and often suddenly change course while underwater. In this, they are masters at confusing the photographer as well!
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#penguin #gentoopenguin #Antarctica #climatechange #climatechangeisreal

Photo by @DaisyGilardini / Pure power and focus! I love being among bears during the salmon run. It always impresses me how much power and focus they show while fishing, and yet they can be so goofy at the same time.
Their techniques vary depending on their mothers‚Äô teaching, and their confidence grows with age. The youngest tend to splash around, running like crazy, and seldom catch a fish. The older ones just walk up quietly and observe the salmon for a while without moving a single muscle. Then, with a precise jump and powerful paws, they firmly catch the fish, one after another.
Just before hibernation, bears enter a phase called hyperphagia, in which their appetite is dramatically increased. They can eat several dozen fish in one session, for a total of more than 50 kg (110 pounds).
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #Alaska

Photo by @daisygilardini / Male and female reindeer both grow antlers. Males shed their antlers at the end of the mating season, usually in early December. Females keep their antlers throughout the winter months, when they may be pregnant and at their most vulnerable.
I shot this image in early April, during my recent assignment in Svalbard. These two females started to spar whenever they got close to each other, competing for food in small patches of ground with no snow. The dominant females are often those with the largest antlers.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#Svalbard #reindeer #svalbardreindeer #wildlifephotography #iceberg #arctic

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Like a ghost, this beautiful spirit bear appeared in an opening through the trees, deep in the thick Great Bear Rainforest in coastal BC.
The complex and rich diversity of wild species in the temperate rainforest‚Äôs ecosystem is fascinating.
The Pacific Northwest temperate rainforest covers much of the coastline from California, Oregon, and Washington State up to BC. Taken together, it forms one of the largest biomasses of any place on Earth. Broader interpretations also include southeast Alaska and parts of Wyoming and Montana.
Apex predators include black bears, grizzlies, Kermode bears, wolves, mountain lions, bobcats, lynxes, and coyotes.
Salmon come back in cycles to spawn in the same rivers, in the same places where they hatched. They are the connection between the ocean and forest and provide essential nitrogen for the tree to grow old and strong.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#spiritbear #kermodebear #blackbear #greatbearrainforest #britishcolumbia

Photo by @daisygilardini // Kamchatka lies on the ‚ÄúRing of Fire,‚Äù a long horseshoe-shaped seismically active belt of earthquake epicentres, volcanoes, and tectonic plate boundaries that fringes the Pacific basin.
Kamchatka is a very powerful land in many senses. Not only the energy of the 160 volcanoes - 29 of which are active - is literally palpable, but also the creatures that call it home are simply amazing.
I was blessed to spend the last two weeks in the Kuril Lake Kronotsky Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, photographing the brown bears fishing during the yearly salmon run.

Spot the leopard! Leopards are some of my favorite big cats mainly because of how adaptable they are. Did you know that leopards are the world's most adaptable and widespread big cats? They live on islands, in cities, and in tropical forests and have been recorded eating more than 106 species of animal worldwide üç¥ This being said they have already disappeared from more than 70% of their historic range. We need to do more for the world's big cats and leopards are a flagship species for this urgent action.

Cheetah cubs hanging out with mom. Cheetahs are the fastest land animal and they purr like house cats!

As with all big cats, the number one reason for the decline of wild cheetahs is habitat loss, followed by human-wildlife conflict where livestock owners kill predators in revenge killings if the predator kills their livestock. Finally comes the illegal wildlife trade, the pet trade is hitting cheetahs hard as is the trade in their skins and bones.

Photo by @daisygilardini // A young grizzly cub finds protection under mama‚Äôs belly while feeding on mama‚Äôs lunch leftovers of salmon.
Grizzly bears are among the slowest reproducing mammals. The cubs will stay with their mother for 2 to 3 years, and won‚Äôt reach sexual maturity until 4 or 5 years old. Mating season is from May to July but actual implantation isn‚Äôt until October or November ‚Äî and then only if the female is in good health and has enough fat reserves to sustain offspring through the cold, harsh winter months.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Photo by @daisygilardini // Female and male walruses both grow tusks, but they differ in size. Male tusks can reach up to 40in (102cm) while female tusks are usually 25% shorter. Walruses are classified as part of the Odobenidae family, Greek for ‚Äúone that walks with teeth.‚Äù
They have many uses for their tusks. They use them to help themselves out of the water onto the ice. They also use them to defend themselves from polar bears and killer whales, their main predator. They use them to establish dominance in their peer group and maintain territory during mating season. They also use them to carve breathing holes in the ice and tear open bigger prey, such as seals, before eating them.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

I like to photograph wildlife in its environment and sometimes find that a ‚Äúsee/don't see‚Äù portrait is actually more interesting than a clear one.

Photographing through thick vegetation can be extremely tricky from a technical point-of-view, as the camera always wants to focus on the leaves close to the camera instead of the bear behind the leaves.
Everything came together when the bear suddenly turned his head towards me at just the right time for me to be able to focus on his eyes and ears.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

A jaguar cub trips a remote camera trap set in the canopy of a large tree in the Brazilian Pantanal.

This region has become a success story for jaguars as a species as, historically, many were hunted on ranches in the region due to conflict between jaguars and cattle. Jaguar ecotourism in the Pantanal now generates nearly $7 million USD annually, while damage caused by this population equates to about $121,000 annually. This is HUGE because it shows that jaguars are worth more alive than they are dead, even to ranchers who rely heavily on cattle production.

The jaguar population in this region is doing great and represents one of the highest densities anywhere across the jaguars' current range. By visiting places like the Pantanal your tourism dollars are directly benefitting local big cat populations and conservation!

Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more shots and facts about big cats around the world üêÜ

They‚Äôre found no more than 45 kilometers from land and will return to land at nightfall.

Other species, like Ad√©lie and chinstrap penguins, have seen significant declines, however. Scientists believe changes in penguin populations on the Antarctic Peninsula are closely related to climate change and the availability of food preferred by different penguin species.

Two 14-month-old tiger cubs at their waterhole in Bandhavgarh National Park, in India. I nicknamed the back one "smasher" because that is literally what he did ‚Äî he smashed the box of my remote camera trap with his paw and it fell into the water. But my efforts were not in vain: I got this image of these beautiful cats as part of a sequence. If there is one place in India where I have spent more time looking for tigers than anywhere else, #Bandhavgarh is it, and it not only has good densities of the big cat but the habitat lends itself to a high chance of seeing tigers in the wild. This is also the place where the first white tiger ever seen was caught in the wild more than 60 years ago. The park is open from October-June and the best time to spot a tiger is in April-June. ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini // Photography is all about light. The dullest of subjects can be transformed into the most amazing and mesmerizing of images if shot in the right light. I‚Äôm constantly looking for special light opportunities when in the field.
On this particular day, the sun was setting fast while we were cruising along Botswana‚Äôs Chobe River. We spotted a group of elephants coming in to drink.
It‚Äôs always challenging when you have large groups of animals, as the scene can sometimes become confusing in a hurry. In these instances, I prefer to use a long lens in order to zoom in and isolate details.
In this instance, I spotted the beautiful highlights on the elephant‚Äôs trunk and tusk.
By underexposing almost three full stops, I darkened the background which made light on the elephant‚Äôs trunk pop out.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#africa #chobenationalpark #elephant

Photo by @shannon__wild // There are few moments that have truly overwhelmed me, and I take pride in being able to keep my emotions in check while working, but as soon as the light disappeared and it was time to let this Temminck‚Äôs Pangolin go on with its evening, I started to cry. I was so overcome with gratitude and wonder at the opportunity to see such a beautifully unique animal, one I never thought I‚Äôd have the chance to see, given its status as the most trafficked mammal on the black market, meaning all 8 species of Pangolin throughout Africa and Asia are in danger of extinction. To witness one of these gentle, docile creatures as it searches for ants and termites to eat, left me in complete awe as well as disbelief that people could be so cruel to these helpless animals.

They spend their days at sea, hunting for fish, squid, and krill. They usually lay two eggs in a nest built out of little stones. The chicks remain in the nest for roughly a month, where their parents look after them until they‚Äôre ready to go to sea.

The Kamchatka brown bear is the largest bear in the whole of Eurasia. A type of brown bear, it can weigh up to 650 kg and measure 3 meters tall. They eat everything, from seven different types of salmon to pine nuts and berries. In a few remote, protected areas in Russia's Kamchatka peninsula, these brown bears reach their highest densities on Earth. However, increased road construction and mineral exploration are fragmenting populations across the peninsula. There may be only 10-14000 of these incredible bears left in Kamchatka (an area the size of California). We need to find ways to live alongside wildlife like these bears. They are apex predators and critical umbrella species for entire ecosystems.

Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more shots of incredible wildlife, people, and wild places from around the world.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Bears (black, Kermode, and grizzly) are paramount species in British Columbia. They play an important role in First Nations culture and are an important source of income for local stakeholders in terms of tourism and recreational activities.

Bears help maintain a healthy ecosystem by scavenging on dead carcasses and helping keep herbivore populations such as deer and moose in balance.

More importantly, bears bridge the gap between the ocean and the forest. By catching fish and dragging salmon carcasses into the forest to eat, bears help fertilize the soil and enrich it with nitrogen.

A healthy forest nurtures the ground, helps tree roots grow, and provides shade for streams. Cool streams encourage the fish to return and reproduce each year. In the circle of life, everything is interconnected.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.
#britishcolumbia #grizzlybear #brownbear #conservation

A young tiger moves through the tall grassland of #bandhavgarh national park, India. This tiger will soon enter one of the most difficult phases of his life. When he disperses at about 24-36 months of age he will try and find a territory of his own. It is very likely he will move a considerable distance, possibly even leave the safety of this national park to try to find his own home! A young tiger called ‚ÄúWalker‚Äù recently traveled 3000 km in a dispersal journey across 7 districts in Maharashtra. These dispersal journeys are so critical to big cats as they allow males to bring in new genes into far-away ecosystems and national parks! This is different from what female tigers do: they usually stay put, close to their natal range, taking a piece of their mother's range or settling nearby. Photo by @daisygilardini / The plains zebra, with a decreasing trend population, is classified as a ‚Äúnear-threatened‚Äù species in the IUCN Red List. Threats to zebras include drought, human conflicts such as wars and civil unrest, the bushmeat trade, and hunting for their skins and body parts.

Interior designers all over the world with an eye for symmetry and design have been drawn to nature‚Äôs designs for inspiration for centuries. There‚Äôs a fine line between inspiration and exploitation, however. Be it elephant ivory, precious stones, marble, rare tropical wood, or animal skins, exploitation must come to an end at some point.

I‚Äôd rather photograph the wonderful patterns of a zebra‚Äôs stripes, print the image, and hang it on a gallery wall than walk on a zebra‚Äôs hide as a rug.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

#zebra #SouthAfrica #SabiSands #conservation

Photo @jasonedwardsng. The Kimberley region of Australia experiences some of the largest tidal changes in the world. At high tide, this large saltwater crocodile emerged onto a sheltered cliff above a river to thermoregulate and bask. Large populations of these powerful predators make it unsafe for humans to swim.

Photo by @daisygilardini / Two newborn polar bears follow their mom, walking on the frozen tundra. During the first cold weeks outside the warmth and coziness of the maternity den, polar bear cubs learn to survive the harsh environment. Shy and prudent at first, the cubs follow mama step-by-step. Not long afterward, they will learn how to play and venture a bit further away, all the while gaining strength and independence.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Photo @jasonedwardsng. This is the critically endangered white-bellied heron. When I photographed this individual in a remote alpine river valley in Bhutan, there were only 26 individuals remaining in the wild. It is always an emotional and exhausting experience capturing species that are on the brink of extinction.

Check out my new book ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô in my bio link @jasonedwardsng

Photo by @daisygilardini / King penguins commute every morning from the colony to the beach, like diligent workers commuting to work in the big cities. They then jump into the sea to fish for the day.
I was fortunate to spend a full week in the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) in late October, following them. Rain or shine, I was there ‚Äî at the beach ‚Äî witnessing the parade and trying to capture the elegance of these gentle creatures in the morning light.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

#conservation #Antarctica #penguin #kingpenguin #FalklandIslands #Malvinas #climatechange

ph_descripcion:
Photo @jasonedwardsng. Whale sharks are the largest fish in the sea. Yes, they are sharks, not whales. They are so big that they create an ecosystem around their own bodies attracting smaller fish and organisms, that in turn attract larger species that might feed on these other species. The whale shark also has a host of small fish that benefit from its filter-feeding strategy.

Although it appears they are not harvested for their flesh, these ancient denizens of the ocean are poached for their enormous dorsal fins. I once witnessed a giant fin decorated as a Christmas tree in a restaurant in Bangkok.

Check out my new book ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô in my bio link @jasonedwardsng

#natgeowild #conservation #whaleshark
#underwaterphotography @seacam_official #livingfossil

Photo by @amivitale // Elephant keeper Lemarash Kalteyo touches the ear of one of the orphans at northern Kenya‚Äôs Reteti Elephant Sanctuary (@r.e.s.c.u.e). As much as 20 percent of an elephant's body‚Äôs surface area is in its ears, which feature an intricate pattern of blood vessels. The vessels themselves can dilate, allowing them to release heat under the hot African sun. Their ears also function as fans, cooling the rest of their bodies.
‚†Ä‚†Ä
@r.e.s.c.u.e is celebrating its sixth anniversary. Please follow them and @amivitale and learn all the ways to support these magnificent people and creatures.

#conservation #elephants #stoppoaching #kenya #babyanimals

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Leopard marking its territory.
There are nine sub-species of leopards on earth, occurring from the southern tip of South Africa's Cape mountains to the island of Java in southeast Asia. The leopard can live in true deserts, tropical forests, and even in the Russian tundra where it drops to below 10 degrees celsius! The biggest threats facing leopards in Africa include the illegal skin trade, wire snare poaching, and human-leopard conflict.

A male lion looks at my vehicle on Kenya‚Äôs #MaasaiMara ü¶Å This male lion is in his prime and one of the most important things that he does as part of his daily life is moving through, vocalizing, and scent marking his pride's territory. This is critical in making sure that male lions from adjacent territories don‚Äôt enter and kill his cubs. The act of killing cubs by rival males is known as infanticide and the reason male lions (like other cats) do it is to advance their own genetics and reproductive ability in as short a time as possible.

I had to consider the safety of my equipment while figuring out how to light the subject, and also show both the beauty and the uncanny landscape that this famous cat lives in!

A male tiger rushes out from a dry riverbed in full charge. Large male tigers like this one can be fiercely territorial, easily covering a range of 200-500 km2. In that range a male tiger will mate with several females, warding off other males and, if in his prime, killing the cubs of other males. A large male tiger like the one in this photo can easily maintain his territorial dominance for about ten years, before slowly giving way to younger, fitter males. Photo by @shannon__wild // The experience still leaves me with so many questions. After spending several hours with a troop of baboons, I was able to gradually sit closer and closer without disturbing them. After a while, I was within a couple of meters as little ones played and adults foraged. As I sat in the shade near this lone male, he barely opened his eyes to me. He seemed so peaceful and yet at the same time defeated.

Was he a former high-ranking member of the troop and now relegated to the outskirts? His scars seem to suggest this is the case but I'll never know. Instead, I have this image to ponder what exactly he may have been pondering.

Follow @shannon__wild for more photos and videos of wildlife from around the world, where she also shares her camera settings for budding photographers.

To me, they represent the ultimate embodiment of what it means to be a large predator: stealth, physical strength, and camouflage. These cats are on the comeback trail in Brazil‚Äôs Pantanal with many ranchers choosing tolerance over persecution of these cats. The reason: they are worth millions to the photo ecotourism sector. ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini // Kamchatka lays on the ‚ÄúRing of Fire,‚Äù a long horseshoe-shaped seismically active belt of earthquake epicentres, volcanoes, and tectonic plate boundaries that fringes the Pacific basin.
Kamchatka is a very powerful land in many senses. Not only is the energy of the 160 volcanoes - 29 of which are active - literally palpable, but also the creatures that call it home are simply amazing.
I was blessed to spend some time in August in the Kuril Lake Kronotsky Reserve, a Unesco World Heritage Site, photographing the brown bears fishing during the yearly salmon run.

Follow me, @DaisyGilardini, for more images and stories behind the scenes.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @DaisyGilardini / Each November, early in the month, chinstrap penguins return to their nesting sites to find their mates.

As with many species of penguins, both parents take turns of 5 to 10 days to incubate a pair of eggs laid in late November or early December.

Once the chicks hatch, both adults will alternate time out at sea feeding themselves and time at the nest feeding the chick through regurgitation.

During the shift change, the couple engages in an ecstatic display of trumpeting and head swinging, which helps consolidate possession of their nest site.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#penguin #chinstrappenguin #climatechange #conservation #antarctica

Photo by @daisygilardini / During the salmon run, brown bears are totally focused on catching fish whenever they‚Äôre near a river. They need to build up the fat reserves necessary to hibernate during the long, cold winter.

They pay little or no attention during this time to the photographer who lies belly flat on a beach to capture the action! They don‚Äôt see us as prey, danger, or competition for food.

To be honest, they are extremely tolerant creatures. I love spending time with them as they always make me smile!

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#grizzlybear #bronwbear #Alaska #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @Shannon__Wild // The southern ground hornbill is the largest hornbill species in the world. Adult males have red bare facial skin while females have a patch of dark violet-blue on the throat. The adult plumage develops at about three years of age, and the facial skin will progressively turn pink, orange, then red over the three to five-year period.

Their numbers have been declining, due in part to persecution, habitat destruction, cultural beliefs, and other factors. They are listed globally as 'Vulnerable' by the IUCN as of 2018, and as 'Endangered' in South Africa, Lesotho, Namibia, and Swaziland.

However, research and conservation groups like @ground.hornbill are working to slow and then reverse the decline of this incredibly unique bird.

Follow @Shannon__Wild for more photos and videos of wildlife from around the world, where she also shares her camera settings for budding photographers.

#shannonwild #groundhornbill #southerngroundhornbill #africa #bird

ph_descripcion:
It's World Rhino Day! A day of awareness for all rhino species across the globe, including these white rhinoceros on Borana Ranch, Laikipia, Kenya. Believed to be extinct in the late 19th century, a small population of fewer than 100 individuals was discovered in 1895 near KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Thanks to over a century of conservation work, around 18,000 white rhinoceros now exist in protected areas and private game reserves across South Africa, Namibia, Zimbabwe, and Kenya.
(National Geographic Image Collection/Michael Nichols)

An African elephant calf walks alongside its mother at Sera Conservancy in northern Kenya. The largest land animals on Earth, African elephant herds wander through 37 countries. They are vital to their habitats, with up to 30% of tree species in Central African forests believed to require these creatures to help with dispersal and germination.
(National Geographic Image Collection/David Chancellor)

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Female leopard sleeping in a tree protecting her impala under a full moon.
There are nine sub-species of leopards on earth, occurring from the southern tip of South Africa's Cape mountains to the island of Java in southeast Asia. The leopard can live in true deserts, tropical forests and even in the Russian tundra where it drops to below 10 degrees celsius!
The biggest threats facing leopards in Africa include the illegal skin trade, wire snare poaching, and human-leopard conflict.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / A night of ice and fire.

During one of my expeditions in Antarctica, we managed to land on a small island during a breathtaking sunset.

You never know what the Antarctic night will hold for you. Sometimes, a promising sunset will turn on you quickly when low clouds obstruct the horizon. Sometimes, you think nothing is going to happen, and at the last minute, an opening will allow the light to peek through the clouds in an explosion of color. The key is to always be ready, in the right spot at the right moment, and grab the opportunity when it arises.

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#Antarctica #penguin #sunset #polar #chinstrappenguin #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #wildlifephotography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @DaisyGilardini / Pure power and focus! I love being among bears during the salmon run. It always impresses how much power and focus they show while fishing, and yet they can be so goofy at the same time.
Their techniques vary depending on their mothers‚Äô teaching, and their confidence grows with age. The youngest tend to splash and run around like crazy, seldom catching a fish. The older ones just walk up quietly and observe the salmon for a while without moving a single muscle. Then, with a precise jump and powerful paws, they firmly catch the fish, one after another.
Just before hibernation, bears enter a phase called hyperphagia, in which their appetite is dramatically increased. They can eat several dozen fish in one session, for a total of more than 50 kg (110 pounds).

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #Alaska #katmainationalpark #conservation #power

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

A male tiger peers out from the undergrowth after killing a cow in @bandhavgarh_forest_department India. Animal agriculture represents the biggest threat to wild cat populations (along with habitat modification and poaching) in the wild and farmer-tiger conflicts are often a source of frustration for local communities in India. A single cow can represent a family‚Äôs entire income as it continuously produces milk. When a tiger, like this male, kills a cow it is an economic shock.
Reserve edges and buffer zones are often the source of a lot of conflicts as they are the areas where younger animals disperse into, or represent easy pickings for females with young cubs.
Science says that placing cows into protective pens, livestock guarding dogs and rotating the movements of grazing cows represent the key ways to stop such conflicts from happening.
.

Did you know that leopards have been recorded eating at least 106 prey animals worldwide? Small beetles, rats and mice all the way up to a large adult male eland, which weighs close to 900 kg. Although this was only recorded once, it shows the incredible power leopards possess when hunting. If you‚Äôre wondering what the preferred size of meal for a leopard is, then the answer is roughly 15-40 kg! That is roughly the size of a duiker to a smaller female impala.

Photo @jasonedwardsng // The coiled, tubular proboscis of a Zebra Longwing Butterfly in southern Peru. The proboscis emerges from between two large compound eyes in the butterfly‚Äôs head.

It functions like a long, slender straw powered by a muscular sucking pump in the head. However, scientists believe the proboscis also operates as a nano sponge, allowing the butterfly to draw fluids from porous surfaces, droplets and films on plant surfaces.

Please join me, @jasonedwardsng, for my upcoming book "Icebergs to Iguanas" featuring my National Geographic assignments.

Photo by @daisygilardini / I am totally in love with the Svalbard reindeer. How could you not be, with such a cute muzzle?
They‚Äôre endemic to Svalbard and are the smallest of the seven sub-species of reindeer found in the Arctic.
They have adapted well to survive the harsh environment. They‚Äôre very sedentary and therefore have low energy demands, especially in winter, when food resources are low and they have to rely on their reserves of body fat.
Their expected lifespan is around 10 years. Their main cause of death is starvation due to worn-out teeth from grazing on sparse vegetation mixed with gravel.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#reindeer #svalbard #wildlifephotography #polar #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #naturephotography

Photo by @daisygilardini / Emperor penguins are listed as ‚Äúnear threatened‚Äù on the official International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of threatened species. Climate change is the prime culprit.
Emperor penguins are amazing birds. They breed on the pack ice during the Antarctic winter (April to August), facing temperatures as low as -40C. By September, the chicks have grown a thick cover of down, and by December they start going to sea.

During the early spring, male and female emperor penguins alternate between spending time with their chick and foraging at sea. At times, the chicks are left alone in the colony. Often they gather in creches, especially to keep warm during storms.

Follow me @DaisyGilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#penguin #emperorpenguin #Antarctica #snowhillisland #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #wildlifephotography #birdphotography

Though they look like hawks, these striking birds are technically falcons that prefer open country. I spotted this bird on a ranch in Highland County, Florida.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bear fur comes in a range of colors, from light brown to dark brown and black to blonde. Their fur often changes from one season to the next. From a young age, cubs often have a light-colored collar, which usually disappears when they become adults.

I do really hope that this beautiful BC bear, now three-years-old, will keep its wonderful coloring, with its super cute white ear tips and blonde collar!
Bear coats are naturally thicker and more coarse during the winter months. In spring, as the weather warms, bears shed their inner fur and guard hairs. They can look really shabby during this transition period, and funny.
Interestingly, the name ‚Äúgrizzly‚Äù derives from its silver-tipped, greyish ‚Äî aka grizzled ‚Äî fur, though it's commonly believed that the name is taken from the word "grisly," meaning horrible. Not true!

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#grizzlybear #brownbear #Britishcolumbia #conservation #wildlifephotography #naturephotography

Leopards are some of my favorite big cats, mainly because of how adaptable they are. Did you know that leopards are the world's most adaptable and widespread big cat? They live on islands, in cities, and in tropical forests, and have been recorded eating more than 106 species of animal worldwide üç¥ This being said, they have already disappeared from more than 70% of their historic range. We need to do more for the world's big cats, and leopards are a flagship species for this urgent action. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots üêÜ

ph_descripcion:
Photo @jasonedwardsng // Life at the top of the food chain is far more difficult than most would imagine. Unless bonded with a sibling in a coalition, male lions live a solitary existence, hunting alone. They also need to retain control of a pride, which can be very short-lived.

Even with their enormous size - in excess of 225kg (500lb) - and strength, they can easily be injured in battles with rival males or hunting powerful prey such as zebra.

Please join me, @jasonedwardsng, for my upcoming book: "Icebergs to Iguanas," featuring my National Geographic assignments.

#natgeowild #lion #jasonedwardsng #ngorongoro #bigcat #lionking

Did you know that if mountain lions recolonized the eastern United States, 708600 deer-vehicle collisions, 155 human deaths, and 21400 human injuries could be prevented over the next 30 years? That‚Äôs over 2 billion dollars in insurance savings. Yep, by hunting deer, big cats save lives, and who would have thought that? These statistics are based upon a study by Sophie Gilbert and her team! I love big cats ‚ù§Ô∏è

Photo by @carltonward // The Eastern Indigo Snake is native to Florida and can be found in many types of landscapes, including sandhills, oak scrub, mangrove swamps, and pine Flatwoods. They can reach up to eight feet in length and are indiscriminate eaters, feeding on anything from frogs and fish to small alligators and other snakes. As development pressures increase in Florida, the Eastern Indigo Snake‚Äôs habitat is at risk of fragmentation ‚Äî a significant cause of species decline.

Follow @carltonward for more wild moments from Florida.

These reindeer are endemic to Svalbard and are the smallest of the seven sub-species found in the Arctic.
They are found in all non-glaciated areas of the archipelago.

Photo @jasonedwardsng - The Leopard Seal is an Antarctic apex predator. They have become notoriously famous for the way in which they hunt penguins, however the vast majority of their diet consists of krill.

Their teeth are shaped in a way that they interlock and form a filter to trap the tiny krill from the seawater. This individual was resting on a small iceberg in a bay surrounded by hanging glaciers, when he woke he began singing and it was mesmerising!

Please join me @jasonedwardsng for my upcoming book ‚ÄòIcebergs to Iguanas‚Äô featuring my National Geographic assignments.

#natgeowild #jasonedwardsng #leopardseal #antarctica

When I‚Äôm photographing in the field, every time I see a mountain slope in shadow, I look for a backlit subject in front of it.
It took me quite a while on this occasion to spot this gentoo penguin feeding its chick, and I even had to lie flat on my belly to get the ideal angle.
By underexposing the frame 3 full stops, I managed to get an almost totally black background, which in turn enhanced the rim light around the two penguins.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

For my snow leopard assignment for @natgeo, I set trail cameras in various valleys, cliff edges, and caves to get up close and personal with the world's highest living big cat. I would leave these traps for more than a month at a time and the cats would take selfies! The hardest thing about this assignment was working at altitudes of more than 3000 meters above sea level, where oxygen levels are thin. Did you know that snow leopards live between 3000-5000 meters above sea level? Not only do they live their lives at this height but they hunt, sprint, and jump. Adaptations for the cold include an enlarged nasal cavity that allows them to warm the cold air they are breathing into their lungs. Other adaptations for the extreme cold include long body hair with a dense, woolly underfur, and a thick tail that can be wrapped around the body.

.‚Å†

A male lion looks at my vehicle on Kenya‚Äôs #MaasaiMara ü¶Å this male lion is in his prime, and one of the most important things he does as part of his daily life is move through, vocalize, and scent mark in his pride's territory. This is critical in making sure that male lions from adjacent territories don‚Äôt enter and kill his cubs. The act of killing cubs by rival males is known as infanticide and the reason male lions (like other cats) do it is to advance their own genetics and reproductive ability in as short a time as possible. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots from around the world üåç

Photo by @daisygilardini / Spending time in the rainforest is an incredible experience. It involves all senses and perceptions. The smell of trees and mosses fills your nostrils; the rain bouncing off leaves has an almost percussion-like effect on your ears. The raven's call often announces the arrival of the spirit of the forest: the white bear.
The Kermode bear ‚Äî also known as "mooksgm'ol" by the First Nations ‚Äî is a rare subspecies of the American black bear. Due to a unique, recessive gene, it has white-colored fur.
It's always special when a wild animal peacefully accepts your presence and doesn't show any sign of stress or change in behavior.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#spiritbear #kermodebear #greatbearrainforest #britishcolumbia #conservation

Photo by @DaisyGilardini / The elephant is the largest land animal on Earth. It symbolizes strength, wisdom, intelligence, and power, and because of that it's revered in many countries.
They are also a symbol of loyalty and trust because of their tight family bonds and complex social life.
I always feel a deep sense of respect when I'm close to an elephant, quite apart from the culture and symbolism.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#elephant #botswana #africa #chobenationalpark

Photo by @jasonedwardsng - Why stop the poaching of lions? This is why!

For every ecosystem, it is imperative to maintain a stable population of predators. Whether it‚Äôs a coral reef or the African savanna, predators maintain the health and vitality of their prey species whilst contributing to biodiversity.

Please check out the link to my new book 'Icebergs to Iguanas' @jasonedwardsng.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

Young leopards playing while hanging out next to their mom. The cubs will stay with her ‚Äì until she goes to hunt ‚Äì then she will hide them in a safe place until she returns.

Did you know that female big cats are philopatric? Which means that daughters stay near the area where they were born and take a piece of mom's home range? That being said, they have very low tolerance for each other and are fiercely territorial. If you were to look at the savanna where leopards live from a birds-eye view you would see that leopard females live in what we call a matrilineal kin cluster ‚Äì it‚Äôs a cluster of females that are largely all related! Moms, aunts, daughters, and sisters. Male leopards are completely different and travel hundreds if not thousands of kilometers to find their own homes. üè† follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots from around the world üåç ü¶Å
.
.
.
.
.
#leopard #leopardcubs #cats #catgram #catsofinstagram #panthera #bigcat

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // Did you know that a giraffe's spots are as unique as our fingerprints? No two giraffes have the same pattern, and researchers use the different patterns to tell them apart. Those spots are not just for camouflage either, they help them regulate their body temperatures. Beneath each patch is a network of blood vessels and sweat glands to dissipate heat.

This young West African giraffe is browsing outside of Doulouwal Peulh, Niger - a village about 50 miles outside of the capital of Niamey where people live side by side with the endangered West African giraffe in the country's government-defined Giraffe Zone. At one point, the range of West African giraffes stretched across the Sahel, from Nigeria to Senegal. Illegal hunting, climate change and habitat loss all contributed to the population's decline, and by the mid-90s, only 49 remained in this zone.

Today, while still highly threatened, thanks to conservation efforts, West African giraffes number over 600. In December 2018, in order to help the long-term survival prospects of this subspecies, the Nigerien government with help from a team from the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (@giraffe_conservation) and Sahara Conservation Fund worked together to translocate eight giraffes from the Giraffe Zone to the Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve. The idea was to create a satellite population to help their survival.

Learn more, including how to get involved by following @giraffe_conservation and @amivitale.

#SaharaConservationFund #protectgiraffes #giraffe #savegiraffes #niger #didyouknow

These markings are presumed to deter potential predators as they appear as two giant eyes (one on each wing), perpetually looking up.

This species of butterfly is large and aggressive, with claws on its feet that it uses to rake the wings of other butterflies feeding on its preferred food sources.

Snow leopards can live at the world's highest altitudes, and that includes Mount Everest! They typically occur at altitudes from 15-25000 feet but they can go higher, and researchers from the Everest Snow Leopard Conservation Centre found scrapes, droppings, and camera trap images of them living on Mount Everest on the northern slopes of the Great Himalayas range. Millions of years of evolution have made this incredible cat adaptable to low oxygen uptake in its hemoglobin and it is amazing how different we are in living at high altitudes. I remember when I set this camera trap, I would regularly get on all fours, not only to check my composition but to get maximum oxygen. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots üêÜ

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / I have to admit that I have an obsession with bee-eaters! Every time I visit Botswana during the winter months, I spend every morning maniacally searching for them in the thick reeds of the Chobe River. This is the only time of day they huddle together in the first sun rays of dawn, to warm up before taking off for the day.
I'm probably obsessed because I haven't got the perfect picture yet. It's extremely challenging to find them on a reed with a clear view, with no other reeds in front of them. It‚Äôs near impossible, too, due to the vegetation's thickness, to keep enough distance between the birds in the foreground and the reeds in the background, which you need to achieve the perfect blurred bokeh effect.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#Africa #beeeater #birdphotography #botswana #chobenationalpark #choberiver #conservation #togetherness

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // These adorable creatures are a testament to what can happen when we work together and value nature and our environment. In 1990, the global wild panda population was approximately 1,100 individuals, and the International Union for Conservation of Nature placed them on the endangered species list. Thanks to massive Chinese and international efforts, though, the bears rebounded, and in 2016 their status was upgraded to vulnerable. Today, more than 2000 live in the wild. China may be on its way to successfully saving its most famous ambassador, and in the process, putting the wild back into an icon.

My book, Panda Love, features my long-term work made on assignment for @natgeo. See more on my feed @amivitale.

Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bear fur comes in a range of colors, from light brown to dark brown and black to blonde. Their fur often changes from one season to the next. From a young age, cubs often have a light-colored collar, which usually disappears when they become adults.
I do really hope that this beautiful BC bear, now three-years-old, will keep its wonderful coloring, with its super cute white ear tips and blonde collar!
Bear coats are naturally thicker and more coarse during the winter months. In spring, as the weather warms, bears shed their inner fur and guard hairs. They can look really shabby during this transition period, and funny.
Interestingly, the name ‚Äúgrizzly‚Äù derives from its silver-tipped, greyish ‚Äî aka grizzled ‚Äî fur, though it's commonly believed that the name is taken from the word "grisly," meaning horrible. Not true!
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#grizzlybear #brownbear #Britishcolumbia #conservation

Basically, the entire province is considered ‚Äúbear country‚Äù as, outside of the big cities, you can find a black bear pretty much anywhere.

Photo by @stevewinterphoto //

The Cheetah is the fastest land animal on earth and Africa‚Äôs most endangered cat. Cheetahs purr like house cats - which is one reason they are under threat. The cubs are either captured or raised in captivity to be sold as pets to the very wealthy, though only one in six survive the journey to their new prison.

As with all big cats the number one reason for their decline is habitat loss, then comes human-wildlife conflict where livestock owners kill predators in revenge for killings their livestock. Finally comes the illegal wildlife trade, with the pet trade hitting cheetahs especially hard, as well as the trade in their skins and bones.

#cheetah

Photo by @daisygilardini / Before they go into hibernation, bears enter a phase called hyperphagia, in which their appetite is dramatically increased. They need to build up the fat reserves necessary for winter.
Their sole focus is food during this time. They can ingest more than 20,000 calories a day, mainly fish, insects, berries, and whatever other food may be at hand.
I watched this bear family come to the river to fish, in Alaska‚Äôs Katmai National Park. Mothers with cubs are extremely cautious when approaching fishing grounds as they have to leave the cubs unattended, where they‚Äôre at risk of being attacked by other bears.
This particular mama approached the river banks extremely slowly, watching the activity of other bears fishing for quite a while. Only when she saw that the other bears were catching big salmon successfully, she decided to join the party.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#Alaska #brownbear #grizzlybear #conservation #family #wildlifephotography

A male jaguar swims through the river in search of caiman in Brazil‚Äôs Pantanal. This jungle and river matrix is home to arguably the world's most aquatic population of jaguars in all of their range (Arizona to Argentina). They fish, tackle massive 90 kg plus capybara, and even wrestle with caimans. They are larger than leopards (by about 35%) and their affinity to water allows them to open up a variety of foods that classically are difficult to catch for other big cats. This adaptability has served them well and they are even thriving on coastal beaches in Costa Rica where they eat turtles üê¢ Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more shots of cats around the world üåçü¶Å

Photo by @amivitale// West African giraffes browse inside the Giraffe Zone, a government-defined region where giraffes and humans coexist in Niger. There are only about 600 West African giraffes left on the planet (up from a low of 49 in the wild, itself a conservation success). In 2018, the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (@giraffe_conservation), with the Niger government and other partners, moved eight of these highly threatened giraffes from the Giraffe Zone to Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve, where they have been absent for more than 50 years.

This is a hopeful story for an animal undergoing what is being termed a silent extinction across Africa.

Follow @amivitale and @giraffe_conservation to learn more about this inspiring story

#giraffe #giraffes #savegiraffes #stoppoaching #niger #westafrica #africa #conservation #amivitale #worldgiraffeday

Photo by @daisygilardini / Shooting from a low angle makes the subject look bigger, stronger, and more powerful.
When in Africa, we‚Äôre shooting from a high-angle point-of-view most of the time, because we‚Äôre in a vehicle. Being on the ground is too dangerous, and nearly all national parks prohibit it.
During my last trip to Botswana's Okavango Delta, I had the chance to shoot from underground. The bunker was situated close to a waterhole.
I simply loved being in close proximity to the animals, and the super low angle. I could never imagine lying on the ground photographing an elephant passing by! Hides allow you to do exactly that, in a safe environment.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#africa #elephant #botswana #okavangodelta #wildlifephotography

Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bears are solitary animals with large territories and home ranges. They tend to avoid other bears as much as they avoid humans. Contrary to what many people think, they‚Äôre actually very shy animals and are spooked quite easily.
Bears don‚Äôt often encounter other bears outside mating season, due to the vast territories they roam in. They seldom meet, and when they do encounter one another, they‚Äôre not very friendly.
In this encounter, a mother with two cubs is clearly staking a territorial claim over the fishing rights along this stretch of the river.
Even though this looks like a fierce fight, the two bears didn‚Äôt physically touch each other. There was simply a lot of loud growling before the young male was persuaded to move on.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#alaska #grizzlybear #conservation #wildlifephotography

Photo by @amivitale // Yesterday was World Ranger Day and I wanted to honor and celebrate all the incredible human beings who have committed their lives to protecting wildlife around the world! In this photo, rangers give Najin, one of the last two northern white rhinos on the planet, some affection at @olpejeta conservancy in Kenya. These men spend more time protecting these rhinos than they spend with their own families. They have a keen understanding of just how special wildlife is to our ecosystems and livelihoods.

In a world where numbers of nearly all iconic species are falling, I feel a special gratitude to those who care so much that they put their lives on the line to protect them. Asante sante. Please consider following or supporting @olpejeta conservancy to support these special people.

#rhinos #kenya #africa #worldrangerday #rangers #conservation
