Photo by @daisygilardini / A chinstrap penguin struggles against surging waves at Baily Head beach on Deception Island. Surging waves originate from long swells reaching the coastline with its steep beach profiles.
When the wave‚Äôs base moves quickly, it doesn‚Äôt allow time for a crest to form, which translates into almost no wave break. Even though they appear friendly, these waves are actually extremely dangerous because of the strong backwash that follows behind them.
Trying to catch penguins' acrobatics as they get out of the water is a challenge.

Walruses live in shallow coastal areas and need ice to rest on when between dives for food.

Photo by @DaisyGilardini | The Kermode bear (Ursus americanus kermodei) is one of the rarest bears in the world. It is a black bear that has a white/creamy fur, which is produced by a recessive gene. He lives principally on the central and north coast of British Columbia in Canada. Though it has always been illegal to hunt a Kermode bear, it is not illegal to hunt a black bear that may or may not be carrying the Kermode gene. Since 2012, Coastal First Nations have banned trophy hunting from their territory in order to promote bear watching instead. The best time to observe the elusive spirit bear is during the salmon run in September.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini / While it‚Äôs pretty simple to achieve rim light photos in the studio, it‚Äôs a whole other ballgame when in the field with wildlife.‚Å†
There are many factors that have to come together at the same time. Firstly, you need a really dark background. Second, you need low light behind the subject. And third, you need your subject to be right in front of the light source.‚Å†
Pre-visualizing this kind of situation is essential so that you can be ready, with the right camera settings, if and when the bear decides to position himself right at the desired spot.‚Å†
It‚Äôs essential to anticipate and be ready when that happens because usually you only have a few seconds to shoot before the bear moves on.‚Å†
It‚Äôs a lot of work and involves patience and luck. It‚Äôs extremely rewarding, though, when it all comes together ‚Äî like this image of a brown bear I took in Kamchatka, in Russia‚Äôs Far East.‚Å†

Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
‚Å†

Photo by @daisygilardini / Gentoo penguins start breeding between two and four years old. They usually lay two eggs, which hatch after 34-37 days. Both parents take care of incubating the eggs. Later, they take turns feeding the chicks, alternating between time spent at the nest and at sea feeding.
For the first couple of weeks, the tiny chicks will stay in the nest, protected from weather and predators, tucked under their parents‚Äô brood pouch, peeking out only to be fed or on unusually warm days.
Once they grow in size to where they‚Äôre no longer able to fit their full body under the brood pouch, they‚Äôll stay in the nest for another couple of weeks before venturing out with all the other chicks, where they form cr√®ches ‚Äî nurseries.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories

#Antarctica #penguin #gentoo #gentoopenguin #conservation #climatechange

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski - Wild horses grazing under stormy skies of mammatus clouds along the Great Basin Desert. Wild horses are indigenous to North America, with fossils dating back roughly 1.2 million years. During this time period, they migrated throughout South America as well as Eurasia, using the Bering Land Bridge as a crossing. Today, wild horses can be found in 18 states throughout the US and are always a great sighting. Their lean physiques, shaggy fur, and wary behavior near humans are the easiest way to differentiate feral horses from domesticated ones.

A leopardess named Marula warms up in the first light of the morning sun. There is something almost regal about her gaze. Leopards are some of my favorite big cats, mainly because of how adaptable they are. Did you know that leopards are the world's most adaptable and widespread big cat? They live on islands, in cities, and in tropical forests, and have been recorded eating more than 106 species of animals worldwide üç¥ This being said, they have already disappeared from more than 70% of their historic range. We need to do more for the world's big cats and leopards are a flagship species for this urgent action. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots üêÜ

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski - This little cute antelope here is called a #dikdik, a tiny antelope found throughout eastern and southern Africa. They‚Äôre roughly 16 inches at the shoulder and weigh between 6-12 lbs. They‚Äôre extremely skittish, understandably considering where they sit on the food chain. Due to their size, they‚Äôre hunted from the air, land, and water by a wide variety of predators. Dik-diks prefer forested areas where they can blend in and hide, relying on their large ears, wide eyes, and keen sense of smell to detect predators.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini | When it comes to silhouettes, less is more!

The key to success is to look for a clearly outlined subject and avoid overlapping multiple subjects. Keep in mind that the goal of a silhouette is to render your subject as a shape with a clearly defined outline, with no color or texture. So the shape needs to be absolutely perfect to work.

In contrast to normal portraits, when I like the subject to look at me ‚Äî possibly with the head tilted a bit in order to see both eyes, creating a 3D effect ‚Äî I find that profiles work best when shooting silhouettes.

When photographing elephants along Botswana‚Äôs Chobe River, it‚Äôs always a challenge to get a clear view of an elephant‚Äôs entire body in silhouette. As one is often shooting from a boat, the horizon line tends to cut the subject in half, something I really don‚Äôt like.

In this instance, the elephant was on a high river bank. By lying in the boat as flat as possible, I was able to get the horizon line right where I wanted it to be.

I waited for the elephant to lift his trunk, to give my image more depth. Coincidentally, the elephant flicked his tail, an extra detail which made all the difference.

#elephant #botswana #africa #silhouette #sunset

Jaguars are not only the best swimmers in the big cat kingdom, they are also very competent climbers. For over 2 decades on many trips to the Brazilian #pantanal, I have seen jaguars 20 or 30 feet high in the branches of some large riverine trees. They probably do this in order to cool down, sleep (because what cat doesn‚Äôt love sleeping in a tree?!), and as a vantage point to stake out prey on their riverine habitat. Jaguars are the perfect aquatic predator, regularly hunting anaconda, caiman (a large crocodilian), and capybara that bask on the river edge. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more jaguar images üêÜ

Photo by @daisygilardini | Play is very important for each animal species as it helps the newborns grow stronger, build self-confidence, and learn to socialize and hunt. Besides the biological importance of playing, this behavior gives us ‚Äî the photographers ‚Äî great photo opportunities.
The IUCN Red List lists lions as ‚Äúvulnerable.‚Äù The population is decreasing and is down to 23,000-39,000 individuals left.
Major threats include human-wildlife conflict, territory fragmentation, habitat loss, and trophy hunting.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini / The Ad√©lie penguin is one of the three species of ‚Äúbrush-tailed‚Äù penguins. They‚Äôre also one of the two true Antarctic species, along with emperor penguins. Despite their modest size, relative to their larger cousins, Ad√©lie penguins have outsized personalities.
They‚Äôre particularly photogenic because of their characteristic white eye-ring and their ability to raise their hind-crown feathers, which form a diagonal occipital crest when displaying.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#penguin #ad√©liepenguin #conservation #antarctica #climatechange

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Steve Winter @stevewinterphoto //

The Cheetah is the fastest land animal on Earth and Africa‚Äôs most endangered cat. They can clock a top speed of close to 90 km/hr and even purr like house cats! This is just one reason they are under threat, as the cubs are either captured or raised in captivity to be sold as pets to the very wealthy, though only one in six survive the journey to their new prison. Recent sting operations have shown this in East Africa!
As with all big cats, the number one reason for the decline of wild cheetahs is habitat loss, followed by human-wildlife conflict where livestock owners kill predators in revenge killings if the predator kills their livestock. Finally comes the illegal wildlife trade; the pet trade is hitting cheetahs hard as is the trade in their skins and bones. Recent research led by Sarah Durant and colleagues suggests there may be as few as ~7100 cheetahs left in Africa, and that if their populations are to survive, they need good protection inside national parks to offset losses in community areas where they clash with farmers! Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cats üêÜ
.
.
.
.
.
#cheetah #cub #baby #conservation #wildlife #wilderness #beauty #cheetahs

The most difficult assignment I ever worked on was on snow leopards. The main reason: oxygen (or a lack thereof). When I worked with some of the best Indian biologists, including @raghuchundawat, we did so at over 4000 meters. Oxygen levels at this altitude are about 40% lower than at sea level. When I set this camera trap I regularly got on my knees so I could breathe easier! Snow leopards don‚Äôt struggle though, they can go even higher to 5400 meters! They are truly incredible cats ü¶Å follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cats üêÜ
.
.

.
.
#leopard #snowleopard #bigcat #catsofinstagram

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Contrary to what many people think, bears don‚Äôt have bad eyesight. Their vision is similar to that of a human being during daylight hours, but it‚Äôs much better at night.
This is due to a reflective layer or lining, called the tapetum lucidum, at the back of the eye.
The misconception about bears having bad eyesight is probably due to the fact that bears trust their nose more, even when they see well. Biologists who have studied bear behavior for years have found bears ‚Äúinterpret ‚Ä¶ the world based [more] on smell than sight.‚Äù
When a bear stands up, it‚Äôs not just to see better but also ‚Äî more importantly ‚Äî to smell better and use all its senses to study the situation in front of it.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#grizzlybear #brownbear #britishcolumbia #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini | Keeping wild animals as pets has always bothered me, especially when we‚Äôre talking about birds. I find that keeping a flying animal in a confined space, like a cage, is particularly cruel. Birds are meant to fly free in the sky, with no boundaries.
Unfortunately, in the United States alone, more than 5 million households have a bird as a pet.
Scarlet macaws are beautiful, colorful birds, and that‚Äôs probably why many people keep them as pets. They lead long lives, 40 or 50 years in the wild, and can reach 75 to 90 years in captivity. Even though they can be extremely affectionate, they can become aggressive when bored.
They‚Äôre also extremely noisy. In nature, their high-pitched screams can be heard miles away, to locate their groups.
It‚Äôs illegal to keep macaws in captivity in Costa Rica. That has allowed the population to recover in the wild.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#costarica #osapeninsula #macaw #scarletmacaw #parrot #monogamous

Photo by @amivitale // A black rhino grazes at @olpejeta Conservancy in northern Kenya. In the early 1970s, the population of eastern black rhinos stood at about 20,000 animals but because of industrial-scale poaching, tragically, their numbers plummeted to less than 350 left by the late ‚Äò80s! In 1993, Ol Pejeta brought 20 black rhinos to establish its black rhino conservation program and today, just three decades later, they have three generations of rhinos and they just celebrated a HUGE MILESTONE in black rhino conservation with the birth of their 150th black rhino.

Learn more, including how to get help, by following @olpejeta and @amivitale for more stories.

#rhinos #blackrhinos #Africa #Kenya #wildlife #environmentalism #conservation

Photo by @amivitale // Suyian, the first elephant rescued by northern Kenya's Reteti Elephant Sanctuary (@r.e.s.c.u.e), is comforted in her first moments after arrival. @r.e.s.c.u.e is the first Samburu community-owned elephant sanctuary in Africa, and wildlife keepers there are working to rehabilitate abandoned and orphaned elephants in order to return them to the nearby wild herds.

This elephant sanctuary is the culmination of a two-decade-long process of tipping conservation upon its head-protecting wildlife for, and not just from, people. In that sense, the sanctuary is as much about people as the elephants. Community ties to wildlife grow stronger with each passing year.

Learn more, including how to help, by following @amivitale and @r.e.s.c.u.e.

@sararafoundation @kenyawildlifeservice #babyanimals #elephants #babyelephants #kenya #conservation

A male jaguar swims through the river in search of black caimans in Brazil‚Äôs Pantanal. This jungle and river matrix is home to arguably the world's most aquatic population of jaguars in all of their range (Arizona to Argentina). They fish, tackle massive 90 kg plus capybaras, and even wrestle with caimans. They are larger than leopards (by about 35%) and their affinity to water allows them to open up a variety of foods that classically are difficult to catch for other big cats. This adaptability has served them well and they are even thriving on coastal beaches in Costa Rica where they eat turtles üê¢ Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more shots of cats around the world üåçü¶Å

Photo by @amivitale // Wild elephants roam at the Manyara Ranch, a 35,000-acre conservancy, which over 50 different types of mammals call home. Since the introduction of Honeyguide Foundation (@honeyguide_tz) tracking dogs to aid in conservation efforts, poaching on the ranch has plummeted. ‚ÄúThese days, not only does an elephant die naturally, its tusks are left intact. This would have never happened before,‚Äù says Fidelis Olekashe, who manages the ranch.

Please follow @amivitale for more stories about our connections with nature.

#DontLetThemDisappear #elephants #tanzania #conservation

Two brothers and their sister relax in a mud wallow in India‚Äôs Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve. Did you know that tigers have naturally high rates of turnover in their populations? Their annual mortality is about 25% but as long as they have adequate densities of prey they can survive and even increase in a landscape. Tigers are the world's largest big cat, reaching up to roughly 300 kg in Siberia which means they need a lot of food. For their populations to really thrive they need about 50-60 prey animals per square kilometer! That‚Äôs a lot of deer, gaur, sambar and even rhino to feed them! Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat facts and photos üôå

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / A group of chinstrap penguins play-climb up a slippery iceberg.
When it comes to interpreting animal play, scientists are divided between those who anthropomorphize behaviour and those who try to find more science-based explanations for certain behaviours.
While it‚Äôs obvious play in young animals helps them form social bonds, boosts their self-confidence and strength, and sharpens other skills they‚Äôll need to survive later in life, I really do get the feeling that, when observing animal behaviour on my own, that sometimes they just want to have fun - as we humans do.
In this particular instance, this group of chinstrap penguins was riding the incoming waves to help them hang onto the slippery side of the iceberg.
Once up, they‚Äôd jump right back down and start all over again, repeating it over and over. It was such a joy to look at them having fun!
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#antarctica #penguin #chinstrappenguin #conservation #climatechange

Photo by Steve Winter @stevewinterphoto //

A mountain lion and her young cub trip a remote camera trap in a hidden cave in Wyoming, USA. Did you know that if mountain lions recolonized the eastern USA (from which they are largely absent) they could save human lives and insurance companies a lot of money?! Did you know that around 200 people are killed in the USA each year from the 1.2 million deer vehicle collisions that happen? A single cougar can kill about 250 odd deer in a six year period, now multiply that out over the eastern USA and you‚Äôd have about a 22% decrease in deer accidents. That‚Äôs about 38 000$ saved by each cougar for the insurance companies! It‚Äôs also 5 human lives and nearly 700 human injuries from those accidents. Big cats help humans BIG and we often forget about this! This research comes from Sophie Gilbert and colleagues! Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cats ü¶Å
.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Last October I had the privilege to track grizzly bears in BC‚Äôs Chilcotin region, in my home province.
I planned my visit later in late fall, hoping to get some snow. On the very last day of my assignment, I was rewarded. It was a reward that came with some challenges though.
When you are photographing in a snowstorm, depending on the subject, you will have to make quick decisions regarding shutter speeds.
Fast shutter speeds will freeze the snowflakes, while long shutter speeds will create streaks.
I prefer to freeze the snowflakes when photographing wildlife. When photographing landscapes, I shoot using both options and choose between them.
The compression of my big 800mm gave me this interesting image where snowflakes closer to the lens look bigger and out of focus, while the flakes in the distance are more defined.
I converted the image to black and white to emphasize the snow, with the bear almost hidden in the black background.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#Chilcotin #brownbear #grizzlybear #britishcolumbia #canada #conservation #snowstorm

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // West African giraffes browse outside Doulouwal Peulh, Niger - a village about 50 miles outside of the capital of Niamey. The giraffe population in the area made their way here in the late 1980s from neighboring Mali, driven by drought and war. When people in the area first encountered them, "We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. We were frightened. Even the cows were frightened,‚Äù recalled Amadou Hama, a Fulani herder in his 70s. The people overcame their fears, however, and today live side by side with the endangered West African giraffe in the country's government-defined Giraffe Zone.

There are only about 600 West African giraffes left on the planet (up from a low of 49 in the wild, itself a conservation success). In December 2018, the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (@giraffe_conservation), with the Niger government and other partners, endeavored to move eight of these highly threatened giraffes from the zone to Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve, where they had been absent for more than 50 years. The translocation has been a huge success and they are doing well. Follow @amivitale @giraffe_conservation and @sdzsafaripark to learn more and get involved in saving this iconic species.

Learn more, including how to get involved, by following @giraffe_conservation and @amivitale for more stories.

#SaharaConservationFund #protectgiraffes #giraffe #savegiraffes #niger #worldgiraffeday

Photo by Steve Winter @stevewinterphoto //

Snow leopards can live at the world's highest altitudes and that includes Mount Everest! They typically occur at altitudes from 15-25000 feet but they can go higher and researchers from the Everest Snow Leopard Conservation Centre found scrapes, droppings, and camera trap images of them living on Mount Everest in the northern slopes of the Great Himalaya Range. Millions of years of evolution have made this incredible cat adaptable to low oxygen uptake in its hemoglobin and it is amazing how different we are in living at high altitudes. I remember when I set this camera trap, I would regularly get on all fours not only to check my composition but to get maximum oxygen. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat shots üêÜ

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // West African giraffes browse in the Giraffe Zone, a government-defined region where giraffes and humans coexist about 50 miles outside of Niger's capital, Niamey. For almost 50 years, the highly threatened West African giraffe has lived only in this region. Illegal hunting, climate change, and habitat loss have all contributed to the population's decline. An ambitious plan to create a satellite population of the highly endangered West African giraffe was undertaken by the Nigerien government with help from a team from the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (@giraffe_conservation) and Sahara Conservation Fund. Eight animals were captured and translocated to the Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve. This is the first conservation effort of its kind for the West African subspecies.

Learn more, including how to get involved, by following @giraffe_conservation and @amivitale for more stories.

#SaharaConservationFund #protectgiraffes #giraffe #savegiraffes #niger #worldgiraffeday

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // Three young West African giraffes browse outside of Doulouwal Peulh, Niger - a village about 50 miles outside of the capital of Niamey, where people live side by side with the endangered West African giraffe in the country's government-defined Giraffe Zone. Female giraffes give birth standing up and newborns are welcomed to the world with an almost five-foot drop to the ground! However, within 30 minutes they are standing, and only hours later they are able to run with their mothers.

At one point, the range of West African giraffes stretched across the Sahel, from Nigeria to Senegal. Illegal hunting, climate change, and habitat loss all contributed to the population's decline, and by the mid-90s, only 49 remained in this zone. Today, while still highly threatened, thanks to heroic conservation efforts, they number 600. In December 2018, in order to help the long-term survival prospects of this subspecies, the Nigerien government, with help from a team from the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (@giraffe_conservation) and Sahara Conservation Fund, worked together to translocate 8 giraffes from the Giraffe Zone to the Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve. The translocation was a success and all are doing wonderfully.

Learn more, including how to get involved, by following @giraffe_conservation and @amivitale for more stories.

#SaharaConservationFund #protectgiraffes #giraffe #savegiraffes #niger #worldgiraffeday

Photo by Steve Winter @stevewinterphoto //

A snow leopard trips one of my remote camera traps in the high-altitude mountains of Ladakh, India. This image is one of my favorite pictures I‚Äôve ever taken of a snow leopard (cumulatively this trip assignment only yielded about 30 snow leopard images) because it shows beautifully why these big cats are called snow leopards. To capture the tiny snowflakes, I set my shutter speed to be faster at night, and with two off-camera strobes, I could illuminate the snow leopard in the back of the frame. If you‚Äôre interested in seeing a snow leopard in the wild, your best chance is in northern India where snow leopard safaris are available on a weekly basis. Be prepared to breathe deeply though, these cats live at altitudes in excess of 3500 meters above sea level and the air here gets pretty thin! Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more images of big cats üêÜ

Photo by @daisygilardini / Does this look like a familiar face to you? The first thing that came to my mind was the Joker.
This black-browed albatross chick is much more friendly and innocent, though, thankfully. I managed to photograph this in the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas) home to 85% of the black-browed albatross population. They are monogamous, which means they breed with the same partner every year.
They nest on steep, tussock-clad cliffs. They lay a single egg in a nest made of mud, guano, grass, and seaweed, built in the shape of a pillar. The chick hatches roughly after three months of incubation by both parents. They take turns caring for and feeding the chick, alternating time in the nest with time at sea fishing.
The chicks are covered by a pale gray-white down from birth and are extremely entertaining to observe. They‚Äôre ready to leave the nest around March/April.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#albatross #blackbrowedalbatross #chick #Falklands #Malvinas

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski - An uncommon sighting of the #CommonPotoo, an oxymoron of a statement for this nocturnal bird. The hunting behavior of Potoos is quite interesting; they choose a branch that is nearly identical to the diameter of their body to perch on, where they sit completely motionless, at the same angle as the branch. It‚Äôs a clever use of camouflage for hunting. When on high alert from predators, they stick their beaks upward and close their eyes to better blend into their surroundings; a fascinating behavior to say the least. Photographed in Brazil's Pantanal.

Photo by @daisygilardini | Dr. Lynn Rogers, a biologist who‚Äôs dedicated his life to the study of bear behavior and ecology, says the best thing people can do for bears is ‚Äúreplace misconceptions with facts.‚Äù
The myth of the ferocious man-eating bear is a legend proven false by both statistics and anecdotal evidence.
That said, bears aren‚Äôt our cuddly stuffed teddy bears we used to sleep and play with as children, either.
Bears are extremely intelligent and wild animals that, whenever possible, will avoid human contact. The more I spend time with them, the more I learn about patience and tolerance.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore // Malayan tapir (Tapirus indicus) at Omaha‚Äôs Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium. The lovely Malayan tapir thrives at night in the rivers and marshes of Southeast Asia, where its highly adapted nose allows it to ‚Äúsnorkel‚Äù in the water. Though adults have striking black-and-white coloration, baby Malayan tapirs are actually black with white spots, allowing them to blend perfectly into a dark forest floor with dappled sunlight. This camouflage keeps predators from finding the baby whenever mom is away. // Join @OPPO and National Geographic in supporting wildlife conservation and protecting endangered colors for future generations. #shotonOPPO

Photo by @daisygilardini / Gentoo penguins start breeding between two and four-years-old. They usually lay two eggs, which hatch after 34-37 days. Both parents take care of incubating the eggs. Later they take turns feeding the chicks, alternating between time spent at the nest and at sea feeding.
For the first couple of weeks the tiny chicks will stay in the nest, protected from weather and predators, tucked under their parents‚Äô brood pouch, peaking out only to be fed or on unusually warm days.
Once they grow in size to where they‚Äôre no longer able to fit their full body under the brood pouch, they‚Äôll stay in the nest for another couple of weeks before venturing out with all the other chicks, where they form cr√®ches, nurseries.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories

I shot this frame of a jaguar in mid pounce going for a caiman in the Brazilian Pantanal üêÜ I have never seen a species of big cat that is more committed to hunting in water and being so fearless about going into water with large 8-10 foot crocodilians! Jaguars not only go into water they hunt in it and regularly consume anacondas, capybara, fish and caiman! The best place to see wild jaguars on an almost daily basis is the #pantanal where they walk along the river daily, hunt and even mate, all in front of photographers and tourists. Thanks to tourism the conflict between jaguars and people has declined drastically. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more big cat photos like this one üêÜ

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Bears use their paws and claws the way we humans use our hands and fingers.
While their paws are extremely powerful, they can be used for a variety of delicate and fine tasks, such as opening a small clam and extracting the yummy content, or delicately and precisely skinning a fish.
Bears often hold and eat some of their food using both front paws while sitting or standing and sometimes, when seated, use all fours.
Their claws are perfectly designed digging tools, as well. They use their paws to dig for roots, and dig holes to store unconsumed food. They also come in handy when tearing open tree stumps and tree bark when looking for insects to eat.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#grizzlybear #brownbear #britishcolumbia #conservation

Photo by Steve Winter @stevewinterphoto //

The clouded leopard, one of Asia‚Äôs least known cats triggers one of my camera traps in a tropical forest patch in the northeast of India. Until just recently we knew almost nothing about this species of felid. They are completely different to any other cat - in fact they followed a different evolutionary path forming a link between the big and small cat species. They are also almost ‚Äúape-like‚Äù in their appearance having massive paws and short legs that lend themselves to a largely arboreal life (tree living). What‚Äôs even crazier is that they have the longest canines in relation to their bodies making them ‚Äúmodern day sabertooths‚Äù! Coarse estimates suggest there may only be 10,000 mature individual clouded leopards left in the wild. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more images of the world‚Äôs big cats üêÜ

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore // Snowy owl (Bubo scandiacus) at the Raptor Conservation Alliance in Elmwood, Nebraska. Though we think of this bird as living only in the high Arctic, the snowy owl can be found much farther south as it searches for rodents to eat at different times of the year. However, ranging all the way up to the crown of the continent is no problem either. That‚Äôs where this iconic bird thrives thanks to special adaptations. Thick feathers extend all the way to the toes, serving to keep feet warm, while an overall white-and-black color pattern allows this owl to blend in perfectly wherever there‚Äôs snow on the ground. Huge and haunting yellow eyes provide excellent vision for hunting at night. Fortunately, the OPPO phone has a manually adjustable ISO for low-light conditions, making this portrait easier to accomplish. // Join @oppo and National Geographic in supporting wildlife conservation and protecting endangered colors for future generations. #shotonOPPO

A snow leopard stares back at a camera trap I set in the mountains of #ladakh India üáÆüá≥ it‚Äôs currently estimated that snow leopards occupy roughly 90 000 km2 of mountains in the Himalayas in Jammu and Kashmir, Ladakh, Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh, of which about 34,000 km2 (13,000 sq mi) is considered good habitat, and 14.4% is protected. Did you know that the total global population of snow leopards is estimated at roughly 10 000 individuals and these occupy mainly alpine and sub-alpine zones of between 3000-4500 metres above sea level? The biggest threats facing the species include poaching, conflict with livestock farmers, and in future a likely shift in the tree line and suitable habitat due to climate change. Follow me @stevewinterphoto for more photos of snow leopards and other big cats around the world üåé

A hippopotamus trips my remote camera trap in the Kyambura gorge, Queen Elizabeth Uganda. This narrow forest gorge runs for about 11 km through the northeastern part of this national park and although only a few hundred metres wide in some parts, it forms a critical corridor of tropical rainforest in a largely savanna dominated park. This means that animals like chimpanzees, hippos, bushbuck and other forest dwelling species can use it as a corridor. Forest corridors like this are the critical and last ‚Äúlungs‚Äù in many landscapes in Africa, critical for both carbon sequestration and wildlife. Follow me @alexbraczkowski for more on Africa‚Äôs wildlife üêÜ

Photo by @daisygilardini | When I was a child growing up in a small village in Switzerland, I remember going to the forest ponds to collect frogs‚Äô eggs, take them home and see them grow into little frogs, then release them back into the wild. I was fascinated by their transformation, and have been collecting frogs ever since, my entire life. Do you also have any interesting collections?
I photographed this wonderful Emerald Frog in the Costa Rica Cloud Forest.

This tiger subspecies is quite distinct in its appearance with a small ‚Äúbeard‚Äù and mane (similar to a lion). It is also the smallest of the 6 extant tiger subspecies. ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore // Pygmy hippopotamus (Choeropsis liberiensis) at Omaha‚Äôs Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium. Size is relative: this pygmy hippo actually weighed more than 600 pounds (270 kilograms) at the time of this photo shoot! Like their larger cousins, members of this species can graze on land at night, when it‚Äôs cooler out. But when the sun comes up, the hippos head for water in order to keep their skin from drying out. And though they don‚Äôt look it, they‚Äôre able to defend themselves quite well; that mouth combined with all that body mass allows adult hippos to hold their own against most predators. // Join @OPPO and National Geographic in supporting wildlife conservation and protecting endangered colors for future generations. #shotonOPPO

Photo by @daisygilardini / When I saw this moment between two young sibling bears playing with a freshly caught salmon, the first thing that came to mind was my mom saying, ‚ÄòNever play with your food and finish everything on your plate.‚Äù
These two siblings weren‚Äôt fighting over the right to eat the fish but were enjoying tossing it around. In fact they never even finished it.
This year, BC‚Äôs Interior Chilcotin region had a really good salmon run, which was great for the local bear population that depends on fish fat and protein to help them build the reserves necessary for hibernation.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#britishcolumbia #chilcotin #grizzlybear #brownbear #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Creativity is defined as use of the imagination to create original ideas, often ‚Äî but not always ‚Äî in the production of artistic work.
When teaching my students photography, I always ask them what makes an image successful.
To me, an image is strong and catches my attention when it‚Äôs something I‚Äôve never seen before. It could be a different angle of composition, a unique perspective, a new behaviour or an original, never-thought-of-before technique.
A successful image for me is a capture ‚Äúoutside the box,‚Äù where the creative imagination and originality come together. Creativity is surprising your viewer with something unexpected and unpredictable.
Being creative is being able to see things others don‚Äôt notice, or presenting them with something familiar in an unfamiliar way. Being creative is unleashing the constraints of our mind to work with our heart and passion.
I captured this image of an elephant coming to drink at a waterhole from an underground bunker.
The low perspective gave me a clear view of the elephant‚Äôs trunk in its mouth, and the perfect symmetry of the two tusks made the composition unusual.
I overexposed by two stops in-camera to get rid of any details in the sky and allow the viewer to focus solely on the elephant.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#elephant #africa #okavangodelta #Botswana #conservation #wildlifephotography

Photo by @daisygilardini / Grizzly bear fur comes in a range of colours, from light brown to dark brown and black to blonde. Their fur often changes from one season to the next. From a young age, cubs often have a light-coloured collar, which usually disappears when they become adults.
I do really hope that this beautiful BC bear, now three-years-old, will keep its wonderful colouring, with its super cute white ear tips and blonde collar!
Bear coats are naturally thicker and more coarse during the winter months. In spring, as the weather warms, bears shed their inner fur and guard hairs. They can look really shabby during this transition period, and funny.
Interestingly, the name ‚Äúgrizzly‚Äù derives from its silver tipped, greyish ‚Äî aka grizzled ‚Äî fur, though it's commonly believed that the name is taken from the word "grisly," meaning horrible. Not true!
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#grizzlybear #brownbear #Britishcolumbia #conservation

Photo by @daisygilardini / An Ad√©lie penguin propels out of the water at incredible speed. Before leaping from the water onto land or ice, most penguins release air bubbles from their feathers. That reduces the friction of their bodies in the water and allows them to virtually triple their normal swimming speed.

It‚Äôs quite a challenge to freeze the exact moment when they jump out of the water. The trick is to position oneself at an angle where you can actually see them approaching underwater. That way, you can start to focus-track them before they leap.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#antarctica #conservation #penguin #adeliepenguin #wildlifephotography #birdphotography #climatechange

Photo by @daisygilardini / Sometimes, lying on your belly is not enough to achieve a certain low-angle perspective. For this reason, when I‚Äôm in the field, I‚Äôm always looking for depressions in the ground.
Shooting from a low angle makes the subject look bigger, stronger and more powerful.
In this specific case, the three Emperor penguins were standing on a snow-bank. By positioning myself right below the bank and shooting upwards, the three penguins look imposing.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#penguin #emperorpenguin #Antarctica

Photo by @daisygilardini / Arctic foxes are burrow dwellers. They occupy and sometimes share space in burrows that have been dug by other animals.
They breed once a year and can give birth to as many as 15-20 little dark pups in a single litter, but many of those die in their first year of life.
Pups emerge from their maternity den at around three weeks of age.
I photographed this three-month-old Arctic fox in Svalbard in July, at the height of the northern summer, around the time they start wandering away from the den to hunt by themselves.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#Svalbard #arcticfox #fox #arctic #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / All five species of African baboon live in large groups, called troops. Troops can vary from a dozen to hundreds of individuals. They maintain a strict hierarchy of dominance.
Baboons live in matrilineal societies, based on kinship with the female line. Grandmothers, mothers and daughters spend their entire time together, while juvenile males leave the troop once they reach sexual maturity.
Female bonds are strong. Even though the mother may be the principal caregiver for its infant, other females cooperate in child-rearing and are extremely protective of each other‚Äôs young.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore // Fennec fox (Vulpes zerda) at the Lincoln Children‚Äôs Zoo in Lincoln, Nebraska. Though small and secretive, the fennec fox is actually a master of the desert. It avoids the scorching heat by sleeping throughout the day but at night becomes a very different animal thanks to those huge ears! They serve several purposes: to listen for prey (insects and rodents), to avoid predators, and, above all, to regulate body temperature by venting excess heat. Extreme side light on image edges can make photos tricky, but the OPPO phone handled it well, thanks to the ability to manually adjust exposure. // Join @OPPO and National Geographic in supporting wildlife conservation and protecting endangered colors for future generations. #shotonOPPO

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / After mama spent all day in the shelter of a day den in a grove of trees ‚Äî resting, nursing and playing with her cubs ‚Äî she decided it was time to continue her journey to reach the pack ice of Hudson‚Äôs Bay.
Peering through the trees, we could clearly see two ear tags.
Each tag has an individual identification number which corresponds to a lip tattoo. Information about the date and location of the initial capture, as well as health information for each bear, are listed in an electronic database. This helps scientists better understand the bears‚Äô movements and health conditions.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#polarbear #bear #polar #wapusknationalpark #conservation #climatechange #climatechangeisreal

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @DaisyGilardini | Frogs are an "indicator species," those species which give scientists an idea of the ecosystem's health.
Frogs' skin is permeable (they drink and breathe through it), so they're particularly sensitive to pollution. Their number, whether through presence or absence, is an indication of the health of the entire ecosystem.
They're also a key indicator because they're both predators and prey. They keep insect populations under control, while at the same time they're a source of food for many other species.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
Red-Eyed tree frog ‚Äì Costa Rica
#costarica #emeraldfrog #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @journeying_justin // A young lion cub yawns at her mother as she settles in for a mid-afternoon nap. Lions are notorious sleepers, clocking in around 15 to 18 hours of sleep a day. Male lions will get even more, up to 20 hours in a day. Female lions get less sleep because they are more active hunters and are the primary caretakers of young lions.

Follow @journeying_justin for more wildlife stories. #natgeowild #natgeo #wildlife #sleepytime #lion #catnap

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / Shooting from a low angle make the subject look bigger, stronger and more powerful.
When in Africa, we‚Äôre shooting from a high-angle point-of-view most of the time, because we‚Äôre in a vehicle. Being on the ground is too dangerous, and nearly all national parks prohibit it.
I recently had the chance to shoot from an underground hide in Botswana. The bunker was situated close to a waterhole.
I simply loved being in close proximity to the animals, and the super low angle. I could never imagine lying on the ground photographing an elephant passing by! Hides allow you to do exactly that, in a safe environment. Even if the elephants are aware of your presence, they‚Äôre totally fine with that, and in some cases even come to check you out with their inquisitive trunks.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#africa #elephant #botswana #okawangodelta #wildlifephotography

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini | Chinstrap penguins belong to the brush-tailed penguins group, together with their cousins, Adelies and gentoos.
Despite their healthy numbers overall, the population is decreasing in most of the Antarctic Peninsula nesting sites. Scientists attribute the decline to climate change, which affects the abundance of krill, their main food source, as well expansion of the commercial krill fishery, which affects krill numbers as well.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#penguin #chinstrappenguin #antarctica #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #conservation

Photo by @amivitale // Brown bears hunt for salmon at Katmai National Park and Preserve in southern Alaska. The park's wild landscapes span tundra, forests, lakes, and mountains, and it is known for the many brown bears that gather in Brooks Falls to wait for salmon.

With an estimated 2,200 brown bears living in the park, Katmai is one of the premier areas in the world for viewing these bears. More bears than people are believed to live on the Alaska Peninsula. ‚ÄúAs many bear populations around the world decline, Katmai provides some of the few remaining unaltered habitats for these amazing creatures,‚Äù explains the @nationalparkservice.

Follow @amivitale for more stories about our connections to the natural world.

@thephotosociety #bears #alaska #brownbears #rivers #katmai

Photo by @DaisyGilardini / When photographing grizzly bear cubs playing, it‚Äôs important to program your camera settings accordingly. You‚Äôll be amazed to see how fast these little guys can move!
To freeze the action, you‚Äôll need to shoot at a minimum of 1/2000s. If you‚Äôre photographing two cubs, you‚Äôll need a bit more depth-of-field, so both subjects will be nice and sharp in the frame.
I usually prefer an aperture of at least f8. If light conditions allow, I‚Äôll push this even further, to f10 or more.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#alaska #lakeclarknationalpark #bear #grizzlybear

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @journeying_justin // A baby leatherback sea turtle makes its way to the ocean along Costa Rica's eastern coast. These turtles hatch in great numbers to overwhelm predators to increase each individual's chance of making it to the sea. Along the way, these turtles can encounter racoons, seabirds, other reptiles, and more.

Leatherback sea turtles are one of the most widely distributed turtles across the globe and grow as large as a small car, making them one of the largest modern reptiles.

These turtles are threatened by habitat loss and poaching for their eggs and meat. To help nesting sea turtles, turn off your lights at night if you live near the coast and clean up garbage you find when visiting the beach.

Follow @journeying_justin for more wildlife stories. #natgeowild #natgeo #wildlife #seaturtle #conservation

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @amivitale // I have a deep respect and admiration for the grizzly bear. This gorgeous gal snuck up on me as I was putting up my first ever camera trap, so I burst out in song and thankfully she ran away. She came back 24 minutes later for dinner, and my camera caught her as the sun was going down just outside Yellowstone National Park (@yellowstonenps) in Montana. In their expeditions to the American West, Lewis and Clark called the brown bear ‚Äúgrizzled‚Äù for the pale tips on their dark fur, and the name stuck.

Grizzly bears were given protection under the Endangered Species Act in the contiguous United States in 1975, and their numbers have rebounded. Today, it‚Äôs estimated there are between 1,400 and 1,700 grizzlies in the lower 48 and another 32,000 in Alaska.

Follow @amivitale for more stories about our connections with the wild.

@nationalparkservice #bears #grizzlybear #cameratrap #montana

Photo by @daisygilardini / Macaroni penguins have great, strong personalities ‚Äî probably enhanced by their red eyes and their yellow, spiky head feathers.
Even though they remain the most populous penguin species, the International Union for Conservation of Nature‚Äôs (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species classifies them as ‚Äúvulnerable,‚Äù due to their rapid population decline over the past 30 years.
The decline is attributed to a number of factors, including climate change, commercial fishing and increased competition for food.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#macaronipenguin #penguin #Southgeorgia #antarctica #conservation #climatechange

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @journeying_justin // This young leopard sits beautifully camouflaged among the brush in southern Africa. These big cats are incredible climbers and are known for caching food up in trees. As a predominantly nocturnal animal, leopards stalk prey, such as mammals, birds, and reptiles at night when they least suspect it.

Leopards are threatened by habitat fragmentation, which acts to cut individuals off from one another and their food source. Green corridors connecting usable habitat can be a great solution for leopards and all wildlife experiencing habitat fragmentation around the world.

Follow @journeying_justin for more wildlife stories. #natgeowild #natgeo #wildlife #conservation #habitat

Photo by @daisygilardini / You would think that the malachite kingfisher is green in colour, as malachite is a bright green copper carbonate mineral. You would be wrong!
These little African kingfishers have two distinctive colours: a reddish-brown belly and chest and blue backs.
On the top of their heads, however, they have a beautiful mix of blue, green and black feathers that glisten in the sun, much as the mineral does.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini / Polar bears lead solitary lives for the most part. Every year, though, in October and November, they congregate around Hudson‚Äôs Bay in Manitoba, and wait for the bay to freeze before heading out to hunt seals on the pack ice.
Play fighting between sub-adults is common during the long wait for the ice to freeze. This behaviour is good practice for the more serious competition during mating season.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#polarbear #wapusknationalpark #conservation #climatechange #Manitoba #visitmanitoba

Photo by @amivitale // A herd of African elephants moves through the lush landscape of northern Kenya. Elephants have long memories and immense empathy, and they even know how to make tools. They are among the most intelligent and emotionally complex animals on Earth. They are also herbivores, browsing on grasses and leaves and using their powerful trunks to break off large tree branches.

There are inherent benefits in a plant-based diet for humans too. It provides high levels of vitamins, minerals, fiber, and antioxidants. Healthy people, healthy planet, happy pachyderms! // Welcome to the world of plnt¬Æ from @vitaminshoppe. ph_descripcion: Photo by @katieorlinsky // A pack horse named Zane grazes in the high country of the Gila Wilderness, located within the Gila National Forest of southern New Mexico. The Gila Wilderness was the first designated wilderness area in the United States and encompasses 870 square miles of rugged country that includes forest, grasslands, 10,000-foot peaks, scrublands, desert, and one of the longest undammed rivers in the American West, the Gila River. To this day, instead of cars and roads the Gila has horses and trails. Spending time in nature with animals is always a privilege, but that feeling has been especially profound these days. It is a peacefulness that everyone deserves. The Gila Wilderness is one of those special places that gives me hope that humans have valued, and will continue to value, the peace and wonder of nature and protect it for generations to come. // @poloralphlauren is committed to reducing their water use 20% by 2025, achieving net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, and providing resale and recycling experiences to customers in 2022. These key steps are part of their effort to protect our planet.

As you can see from this image, this chinstrap penguin is not shy in climbing a vertical, extremely slippery iceberg.

Photo by @daisygilardini | Arctic terns are simply amazing little birds. With a length of 13-14in (33-36 cm) and a wingspan of 30-33in (76-85 cm) these incredible creatures cover roughly 44‚Äô200 miles (71‚Äô000 km) every year migrating from the Arctic to Antarctica. One of the longest migration known in the animal kingdom.
Their beauty and elegance in flight are breathtaking.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#tern #arctictern #birdphotography #svalbard #norway

Photo by @daisygilardini / Which of these poses you like the best?
Far Eastern brown bears are a subspecies of the more commonly known brown bear.
Even though they're closely related to Alaska brown bears and thought to be the ancestor of Kodiak bears, they're very distinctive in appearance with a wider and longer skull, and longer legs and ears.
Males can reach up to 700 kgs. Their large size is due to access to food sources like salmon, pine nuts and berries.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @daisygilardini / I‚Äôve landed on Half Moon Island in Antarctica dozens of times during my career documenting the polar regions. Quite often we find Weddell seals resting on the pebble beaches that dot the Island.
The seals give birth to their pups in early spring (Sept./Oct.), but it‚Äôs not easy to actually see them. In the last 20 years, I‚Äôve seen a few, but hardly ever in approachable situations.
You can imagine the smile on my face, then, that day we stepped on the beach in early November. Just a few metres from crashing waves on a bank of pure white snow, a mother Weddell seal rested with her young pup. I spent the next three hours observing this cute little baby.
The pup was shy at first. I let him get used to my presence by just standing there, without moving. After a while he grew more comfortable and started playing with his flippers, biting them, scratching and making the most silly grimaces.
It was one of the most precious afternoons I‚Äôve ever spent in Antarctica. While editing the images, I could not stop giggling.
Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.
#weddellseals #antarctica #simplicity #wildlifephotography #climatechange #conservation

Photo by @daisygilardini / I love all animals with long fur ‚Ä¶ especially when backlit.
This waterbuck was grazing in the early morning in a perfect spot along Botswana‚Äôs Chobe River.
I underexposed two stops to get rid of details in the shadow and perfectly expose the highlights. The little piece of vegetation sticking out of its mouth makes it even cuter!
As the name suggests, waterbucks are large antelopes which inhabit areas near water such as plains, woodlands and swamps.
